story: The three residents of Cockenziersquos South Doors were announced as a daily prize winner with Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery this afternoon .Judie McCourt, Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery ambassador, sent her well-wishes to the winners, who have the postcode EH HR.She said: ldquoWhat great news for our winners today!ldquoCongratulations to them and I hope they get themselves a treat with their winnings.A minimum of  per cent of ticket sales goes directly to charities and players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery have raised more than pound million to date for thousands of good causes in Britain and beyond.This draw was promoted by Crisis, which has received more than pound. million in funding from the players of Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery.Crisis is dedicated to ending homelessness and helps about , people each year through education, housing, employment and health services across England, Scotland and Wales.Many good causes close to the winners have also benefitted from playersrsquo support, and local charities can next apply for funding in August.For more information, go to www.postcodelottery good-causes

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: column-connections-key
story: AS WE adjust to a new normal, itrsquos vital we lsquocarsquo cannyrsquo.Getting out to shops, cafes and pubs is important for wellbeing, as much as our economy.Irsquove enjoyed a coffee outdoors, nattering to friends and meeting with constituents.Simple things like that which we once took for granted are to be savoured.But restrictions, whether in the wearing of face masks or social distancing, are also required and they need adhered too.Wersquove travelled a long hard road towards recovery and we just canrsquot afford to throw away the gains made through all that hardship.Besides, the risks are too great. Not only must we protect the vulnerable, but we need to remember that it would be much worse second time around.As wersquore seeing in Leicester, a further lockdown isnrsquot accompanied by the same level of support.The costs to iniduals and businesses is high enough already.The financial hardship would be far worse a second time around.Itrsquos not killjoy rules or needless bureaucracy but essential actions to protect us all from a further outbreak.Follow the guidance and be mindful of others.Lockdown has also shown the importance of connectivity, whether mobile or broadband.Folk have been working from home, kids doing schoolwork and many just keeping in touch with family and friends.Itrsquos an issue I raised in Parliament last week, as many constituents both before and during the crisis were lamenting the deplorable broadband connection.As I said to the UK Minister, itrsquos not asEast Lothian is remote, with the A, East Coast Mainline and National Grid running through it.Yet the medium to the fore during this crisis and in many ways from now on is connectivity. More needs done.Only  per cent of Scotland, yet  per cent of England, is targeted for mobile coverage and the broadband access is similarly worse.As the county needed road and rail, now it needs wi-fi and broadband.The UK Government must deliver for every area.

title: backing-local-businesses-throughout-east-lothian
story: We know that the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown have made le incredibly tough for businesses across the county ndash and we know they need our support now more than ever.So today, we at the East Lothian Courier are proud to launch our lsquoLove Local Businessrsquo campaign and urge people to back local businesses as they attempt to bounce back from the pandemic.Shops, pubs, cafes, restaurants and much more throughout the county were forced to close their doors due to lockdown-related restrictions.Now, as restrictions are eased, East Lothianrsquos MP and Provost have joined the Courier in urging people to lsquoLove Local Businessrsquo and get behind independent businesses.Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, was pleased to back the campaign.He said: ldquoWhile the governments rightly focus on maintaining the national economy, our high streets and local businesses are the backbone of our local economy here in East Lothian.ldquoWe are rightly proud of our status as a tourist hub and wersquore lucky to have so much choice in our towns and villages.ldquoIf we want to conserve the huge local benefits that come from local traders, we will all need to play a part.ldquoMany of our local businesses were pivotal in supporting the community during lockdown. They proved themselves to be an important part of our community.ldquoNow itrsquos time for us to repay that support.ldquoNot only is it good for the local economy, it makes sense for us all as well. The quality of the food and drink the arts and crafts the tourism and leisure and the tradespeople across East Lothian are fantastic. As a constituency, we produce so much of such a high quality that it makes sense to shop local.Provost John McMillan is East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism.He said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has launched its Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian campaign to highlight the work we are doing, in partnership with national organisations and our local businesses, to build East Lothianrsquos economy, support businesses to re-open safely, encourage local residents to continue to support their local businesses whenever possible and re-open East Lothian to tourists in a safe way.ldquoWe are also very pleased to be supporting the East Lothian Courierrsquos Love Local Business campaign as our aims are very much aligned.ldquoDuring the Covid- crisis, we have seen many businesses adapt and continue trading, and provide a first-class service to our communities.ldquoIrsquom sure our residents will want to continue to support these businesses and give a warm welcome to those who sadly had to close but can now re-open.ldquoWe have such a erse business community across East Lothian from our wonderful hospitality industry, world-class food and drink providers, unique retail offering and, of course, our larger industry and hugely important local employers.ldquoWe need to come together in our communities to support local wherever possible to protect local jobs and our economy and indeed to encourage expansion.We all love our local businesses ndash letrsquos rally together now and show them the support they need to get through this tough time.

title: column-great-reconnect-loved-ones
story: THE Scottish Government has officially announced a move into phase  and this week we will see many restrictions lted.The First Minister has made two signicant changes to previous announcements. The first includes the reopening of churches from July , and I know many will be delighted with this change, which will accommodate congregational worship and communal prayer.The second signicant change is that all non-cohabiting partners, and any children under  in the household, can form extended households without physical distancing.In phase , a household can meet up to four other households at a time outdoors, which is up to  people in total.A household can meet up to two other households at a time indoors, which is up to eight people in total and includes overnight stays.I know that many of you will be delighted to be reconnecting with friends and loved ones and I welcome these exciting announcements.Please keep in mind the important policies around social distancing, where you should remain two metres from those not within your household or extended household. Please also note that face coverings are now compulsory in shops, retail and public transport.Throughout the Covid- crisis, it has been concerning to see the rise in anti-social behaviour and domestic abuse locally.I would like to thank the East Lothian Council housing team and the ASB team for their hard work over the last few months and their responsiveness in dealing with the issues which have been brought to them.The police have also gone above and beyond to ensure those who donrsquot have a safe home receive the attention and support they need.If you need support, Scotlandrsquos hr Domestic Abuse and Forced Marriage Helpline is available on   . You can also call the Rape Crisis Scotland Helpline on    , email support@rapecrisisscotland.org.uk or text  .

title: tims-tales-porridge-maker-unexpected-meeting
story: SOME said he was a gypsy, although he travelled alone. He would arrive for a few months in the summer, then vanish until the following year.He was always mysterious as to where he came from and where he was going. He had an accent that some said was Irish, but it was mixed with a most definite local Scots dialect. He was an old man with an unkempt beard. He always wore a bonnet a certain way, and wild strands of white hair grew from the sides of it. While he still had most of his teeth, there was one visibly missing, which was revealed when he smiled. When people asked him his name he would be reluctant to say. People called him the Porridge Maker.His most treasured possession was his cooking pot. It was large and heavy and he would carry it on his back with the help of straps he had made. He tied the lid tightly and all his other possessions would be stored in the pot. It became a kind of rucksack as he travelled.He would walk for miles, humming to himself, singing and sometimes playing his penny whistle. Then he would choose a place to settle for the night, and unpack his pot, and start cooking. He would make an evening broth from whatever he had managed to acquire during his dayrsquos travel. Then under the canopy of the stars, or under the boughs of a treeit was raining, he would wrap himself up in the thick blanket that he used during the day as a kind of jacket.Every morning he would make porridge, and always a larger amount than he would need himself. This was the time when people would enquire as to his purpose and origins. Often it was the small children of the village whose curiosity would make them assemble round him and ask questions. Sometimes they would be shooed away by their parents, but often the older members of the community who had more time would engage him in conversation, and then sit with him.The Porridge Maker had tales and riddles, news from far-flung lands and memories of past deeds and events which made his company fascinating for old and young alike. Soon it became apparent why he would make more porridge than he needed: it was to share. He would share it from his one bowl, which he called his Porridge Quaich. It would be passed round in an almost religious ceremony.But to have a taste of his delicious porridge, a price had to be paid. A story or riddle must be told, a memory shared or some wisdom imparted. The Porridge Maker would listen carefully to everything said. This was one way he gained his vast knowledge of the world and of its stories.The other was, of course, in his travels. As he walked he would observe everything: the way the clouds formed, the song of the birds, the landscape and its curiosities, the way people behaved everything. Then he would just be, and allow his thoughts and observations to mingle. This was how new tales and riddles formed in his imagination.And so as he cooked his evening meal, he would tell stories to himself and whisper his riddles, and he would look forward to sharing them with whoever might come his way and sit by his fire.Then one day, someone recognised him.The Porridge Maker had settled himself away from the road by the River Tyne, downstream from Haddington. He had made a small fire and was cooking a trout he had secretly caught when an old man of similar age walked by, stopped, stared at him, and then made his way towards him.The Porridge Maker thought he was now in trouble. But the old man wasnrsquot interested in the fish. He studied the Porridge Makerrsquos features carefully, then he nodded with a grin.ldquoAye, sae it is ye! said the man with an accusing tone.ldquoAye, fir sure I am maist certainly me! replied the Porridge Maker.ldquoYe cannae bamboozle me, said the stranger with a triumphant mocking laughter, ldquoI thocht I kent ye by the way ye wear yer bonnet and by yer stooped shudder, but noo that Irsquove seen yer face I ken fir sure!ldquoAnd  asked the Porridge Maker, seemingly unfazed by this sudden attempt to unmask his identity.The stranger sat himself down and looked the Porridge Maker in the eye.ldquoI cannae mind yer exact name, he said, ldquobut I ken ye were a Jacobite.ldquoThose days are lang past noo, said the Porridge Maker, still keeping his calm.ldquoAye, they are, thankfully. And they hanged many orsquo the likes orsquo ye.ldquoThat they did, replied the Porridge Maker.ldquoYer a MacGregor, said the old man, ldquoI mind that, and ye hud blood oan yer haunds ater Prestonpans.The Porridge Maker said nothing. He just stared into his fire.ldquoYe sliced a manrsquos heid in twa by the wall.Suddenly the Porridge Maker looked up. ldquoHowrsquod ye ken that  he asked, now startled.ldquoBecause I wis there!The Porridge Maker now looked the man in the eye.The old man continued: ldquoYe were goanie dae the same tae me. I hud nae weapon sae I punched ye.ldquoAye, said the Porridge Maker, ldquoI remember that weel enough, revealing the gap in his teeth that was the result.The old man laughed.ldquoThat punch saved ma le, said the old man, ldquofir it gied me time tae run as ye stood like a stunned rabbit. But I saw ye ater, greetin like a bairn.The Porridge Maker was silent but pursed his lips and nodded.ldquoYe cudnae thole it cud ye  said the man accusingly.ldquoI wis a lad, and arsquo fired up with rage, said the Porridge Maker. ldquoHe wisnae the only one that day I killt. But I vowed he wud be the last Irsquod kill tae decorate anotherrsquos pride. He hud cried fir mercy sayin he had bairns, but I didnae understand his words till after Irsquod cut him.The old man laughed. ldquoSae much fir the great warrior race! Ye deserted after the battle, didnrsquot ye  Ye ran awa like a coward and cudnae gang hame. If the Redcoats hadnae caught ye, yer ain family wud huv disowned ye fir the coward that ye are!ldquoI did go hame after, but I found ma hoose burnt and ma we and bairns slain. Sae I hud nae family left after that time, said the Porridge Maker with a breaking voice.The old man bowed his head. ldquoAye, it wis a sair time richt enough. But the wages orsquo rebellion are unforgiving.ldquoDae ye ken the name orsquo the lad that I killt by ye  asked the Porridge Maker hopefully.The man was surprised by the question, and looked at the ground as he thought.ldquoWull I think, aye, it wis Wull. I mind he wis really feart, poor lad, he carsquod fir his mither as he died.The Porridge Maker lowered his head, reliving that moment he had tried so often to forget.Neither men had yet exchanged their names.ldquoYou hungry  asked the Porridge Maker, ldquofor ye can share whit I have ye huv earned it by sharing yer memory wi me.And so two men, who once had tried to kill each other, now shared a meal.ldquoWull, the Porridge Maker whispered as he ate.He finally had a name for the young lad hersquod slain all those years ago in  at Prestonpans.The deepest wounds of war are often those unseen, and the stories left out by military historians are the stories of lives traumatised and changed forever.Sadly, whatrsquos left of the Prestonpans battlefield site is now under threat by proposed new developments.

title: column-heyday-open-air-pools
story: Open-air pool lidos in England are already open.If we were back in our former holiday heyday, we could offer a choice of three seaside lidos.Swimming lsquopondsrsquo at Port Seton, Dunbar and North Berwick once buzzed with summer sociability in the sun.For families, they offered entertainment, like galas, ing displays, water polo matches and midnight bathing.A fortnightrsquos lsquobucket-and-spadersquo seaside holiday drove the popularity of lidos between the wars. Using the tide to drain and refresh their seawater made swimming both safe and healthy.Dunbarrsquos began in the s. Ringed by an amphitheatre of grassy slope below Bayswell Road, a simple wall trapped seawater at the top of the tide.Between  and the s, this was constantly developed into a magnicent m by m oval lido, with  changing cubicles, seating for , plus a curved pavilion, boating pond and a seaside promenade.In the s, Pondmaster Field could survey all this from his front window in St Beys above.Inspired by Dunbar, Provost John Hall Weatherhead raised pound, to open a lido and pond hall at the intersection of Port Setonrsquos Fishersrsquo Road and High Street in .The hall was a full-blown civic centre, with council chamber, library, tea room and one of only three sprung ballroom floors in Britain.For a town aspiring to lsquoThe Biarritz of the Northrsquo, North Berwick was slow to match Dunbar. Its harbour cross quay included sluices, using seawater ponded behind it to flush out mud.This became an informal swimming hole, with a changing hut called lsquoThe Arkrsquo. The town council replaced all this with a proper m-long art deco lido, seating over , in .Stern, white-clad figures of Pondmasters McCracken, Lemmon or Kennedy ran a tight ship and frowned on horseplay. To outdo its rivals, in  the pond was heated, with marginal success.All three suffered from jet holidays to the sun from  on. Dunbar closed and was bulldozed in .Port Seton, along with its Pond Hall, went the same way in . Despite a local campaign called STOP, North Berwick was last to close, in .It is now a boat park but cubicles at either end survive as monuments to an era.You might re-live that era by visiting Stonehaven... once its lido re-opens.

title: dunbar-sea-cadets-boosted-lockdown-survival-packs
story: Usually, Dunbar Sea Cadets, which caters for  young people aged -, would spend  weeks of the year on the water.However, the thriving youth recreational group has been forced onto solid land due to the global pandemic and instead left to rely on video calls to keep in touch.With some of the youngsters potentially suffering from stress and disorientation that lockdown has created, the unitrsquos commanding officer, Chief Petty Officer Martin Galloway, approached Community Windpower and BeGreen Dunbarrsquos joint Covid- crisis fund for help with an idea.Martin wanted to create wellbeing packs for the youngsters, who are dotted around East Lothian, to help ease any suffering the cadets might be feeling.He said: ldquoWe are a surrogate family to our cadets and volunteers, all people who thrive outdoors and love being active.ldquoLockdown has had a huge impact on how we engage with our young people, some from the margins of society, others in vulnerable set-ups.ldquoEven though we are engaging virtually through digital classrooms with our young people, the impact of lockdown in a rural area such as ours cannot be underestimated and the long-term effects on our young people.The packs have recycled pens, notebooks, highlighters, treats and activity books, but he needed funding to buy them all, which is where the fund came in to supply the full cost of pound,.Martin added: ldquoWersquore so grateful to Community Windpower and BeGreen for supporting the unit on this initiative and we canrsquot thank them both enough.ldquoSome of our cadets are in high deprivation areas, and family incomes have been hard hit as a result of Covid-.ldquoThese packs will be a welcome distraction to the young people and their families.ldquoIt shows that we are still here to help and support them, and that they are not alone.Diane Wood, community benefits director at Community Windpower, which operates the Aikengall Community Wind Farms in East Lothian, said: ldquoWe know Dunbar Sea Cadets is a fantastic group to be part of and provides young people in the area with long-term skills and personal development that they might not otherwise have where.ldquoItrsquos so important we support all members of our communities during this Covid- pandemic, which is why we didnrsquot hesitate when Martin explained what they were planning to do with the funding.ldquoChildren need something to help focus on something positive, to help with their mental health and encourage stimulating activity, and we hope these packs provide something positive for them.

title: north-berwick-church-welcomes-new-priest
story: Father Augustine Bobi replaces Monsignor Brian Halloran, who suddenly passed away on March , hours after conducting his last service.Father Bobi comes from the diocese of Navrongo-Bolgatana in the north of Ghana, sharing a border with Burkina Faso.He was ordained on August , , and came to Scotland on December  last year on a two-year-long sabbatical.He was placed temporarily at St Margaretrsquos Catholic Church in Duns in the Borders and arrived in North Berwick to take up his post on June .After taking some time to familiarise himself with the people and the town, he was working with parishioners to prepare the church so it could open for private prayer.Before the church opened, however, it was professionally deep cleaned and fumigated.The church is now open on Sundays from pm to pm, and on Tuesdays and Thursdays from am until pm.Stewards will be on duty and visitors to the church must wear face coverings and all must comply with social distancing.For more information, contact Father Bobi on  .

title: ormistons-blooming-lovely-gesture-medical-centre-staff
story: Ormiston Blooms Together wanted to show its appreciation for the Ormiston GP surgery and pharmacy staff, who have been working tirelessly through the Covid- pandemic supporting the community.Two planters were presented to Dr Bolton and Jay McNeill last week.Ormiston Blooms Together was donated the planters by local joiner Callum Smith and will care for the planters in the future.

title: letter-week-not-fly-east-lothians-flag
story: However, few could deny that in recent times both the Union flag and the Saltire have become too closely associated with party politics.A suggestion to help defuse this rather sorry state of affairs would be for East Lothian Council to revisit their flag protocol and perhaps incorporate the usage of East Lothianrsquos flag on and outside public buildings.Further, the county flag would more succinctly and effectively reflect and display civic pridethan either the British or Scottish.Remember ndash East Lothian is the birthplace of more than one flag!Chris AskhamMillhillMusselburgh

title: plans-revealed-knock-bank-hall-former-rbs
story: The former Royal Bank of Scotland hall in North Berwick has been at the centre of a bid by new owners to create a home on the site since it was closed two years ago and sold by the financial institute.However, the hall is an extension to a Category B-listed building which would have been the bank managerrsquos home at one point, and listed building consent was needed to change it, as well as planning permission.Both were refused by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, leading to an appeal to Scottish Ministers and the local authorityrsquos Local Review Body.The Scottish Government Reporter ruled that, despite the claims of the agents for the owners that the extension itself was not an integral part of the Category B listed building, and had been added in the s, changes would impact on the Victorian building.Ruling in January, the Reporter said he believed theplanned changes would not only affect the historic interest of the listed building but would adversely affect the setting of the adjacent listed building and be ldquodetrimental to the character and appearance of the conservation area.The original plans for the conversion included a wine cellar and rumpus room as part of the new residence.However, planning officers told East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Review Body that the property was for commercial use and should remain so.They said that the council had received  letters of objection and seven in support of the plans, although they added that five of the supporting letters came from people who did not live in the town and they dismissed suggestions the new owners had ldquorobustly marketed the property for its intended purpose before applying to build the house.The new application proposes demolishing the bank hall, which had been described by some councillors at the Local Review Body meeting in November as ldquounattractive as they refused the original plans.It also proposes to set aside part of the ground floor of the new two-storey home for commercial purposes.In an application to the planning authority, the applicants say that the new home would include  square metres of space for ldquoflexible pop-up commercial business space to be rented short term to inidualsor companies requiring to use it.The plans are now on the council website for comment.

title: 50-000-boost-business-helping-others-cope-loss
story: Sheila Hogan secured funding after winning an Innovate UK award, part of a pound million boost to drive new technological advances.The Biscuit Tin, which was awarded pound,, has been designed to enable the digital transformation of lsquoend-of-lersquo planning.Sheila set up the business following the death of her own parents with a view to meeting a need for iniduals to put in place secure plans for managing their end-of-le wishes.The coronavirus pandemic has brought these needs into focus for tens of thousands of families across the UK, who have now lost loved ones to the virus, and who will now be grappling with many decisions to make in the wake of their untimely deaths, many without any knowledge of what their loved one would have wanted.Sheila, of Dunbar, said: ldquoMy own dficult experience of having to deal with my parentsrsquo affairs whilst going through immense grief made me determined to make the whole process easier for other people.ldquoMy heart absolutely goes out to everyone who has lost a loved one during this pandemic.ldquoThe whole thing has been absolutely heart-breaking.ldquoI founded Biscuit Tin to make the closing down of a loved onersquos le a much easier process than the very manual and protracted process it is today and I feel for each and every person who is having to go through this process right now.ldquoWinning the award from Innovate UK will enable us to rapidly speed up our development roadmap, making even more features available more quickly, and wersquore incredibly grateful to their assistance in helping us deliver the best solution, faster.At the start of the pandemic, Biscuit Tin opened up free registration for the service until the end of  for anyone signing up during the pandemic and has already seen a steady rise in registrations over the last  weeks.During the set-up of a Biscuit Tin account, customers can choose lsquonomineesrsquo to be the executors of their digital vault, allowing access to all their data only when it is needed.The company will be working with Edinburgh-based software development and design agency Bad Dinosaur to deliver the project and the new features will be in place by the autumn.Sheila added: ldquoOur vision for the project is to encourage and support the change needed to the way we all handle the end-of-le planning.ldquoThe key focus being to remove the barriers and empower, enable and motivate everyone to get organised and put their own affairs and wishes in order.ldquoBy making our own decisions and planning in advance, storing it all digitally in one place, we will make a world of dference to those we love, eliminating all the unnecessary hassle and stress and providing peace of mind at an emotionally distressing time of loss.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, offered his congratulations to Sheila.He said: ldquoSheila has risen to the challenge we all face in these times, despite the tragedy shersquos faced in her personal le.ldquoShersquos used her understanding from coping with her own loss to ensure that others will find comfort.ldquoThis award is due recognition of the value of her work.ldquoIt should rightly be celebrated and hopefully many others can now benefit as a result.

title: family-uncover-piece-wallyfords-history
story: Matthew and Caryn Fower, who have three children, were delighted to discover a iety of Scottish-made bricks, including from Wallyford and Prestonpans, at their home on Wemyss Gardens.They were found amongst mixed rubble under a shed which was removed to make way for a new-look garden and patio better suited to their family needs.After posting news of the find on social media, they were inundated by local residents eager to get their hands on one of the bricks as a reminder of Wallyfordrsquos brickmaking heyday.Matthew, who works in IT, started the garden project about a month ago on weekends and on a weekrsquos holiday as he was still working during the Covid- lockdown.Caryn said: ldquoA big shed and around  concrete slabs were taken away as we wanted to level the garden, which was on two levels.ldquoWe wanted a new patio area and walls to make it a better space for the family.They found five lsquoWallyfordrsquo bricks, one from lsquoPrestongrangersquo and dozens of lsquoGISCOLrsquo bricks, which stands for the Glasgow Iron and Steel Company .Caryn and Matthew have kept one lsquoWallyfordrsquo brick and the lsquoPrestongrangersquo brick, which will have pride of place for posterity in a new wall they are building in their garden.The rest have now been given away to neighbours as a thank you for allowing the family to borrow equipment for their gardening work and other residents who put out requests on social media, although some of the lsquoGISCOLrsquo bricks have had to be disposed off.Another two bricks indented with lsquoNiddriersquo and lsquoEdinburghrsquo were also found recently during work in a garden at Whitecraig those bricks have also found new homes, including a friend of Carynrsquos who lives in Niddrie.According to information on the Scotlandrsquos Brick Manufacturing Industry website run by Mark Cranston, the Wallyford brickworks were part of the National Coal Boardrsquos operations from  to . The works were then sold to the Scottish Brick Corporation and closed in , when employee numbers were about .James Burns was the manager at the brickworks from  to  and, in an otherwise undated and unattributed document, held at Musselburgh Library, he described the process of brickmaking at Wallyford.Wallyford had one continuous kiln which held about , bricks, and four square lsquointermittentrsquo hand-fired kilns which held between , and , bricks.The bricks were transported by rail or lorry to wherever they were required. Over time, Wallyford bricks were used in many buildings, including at Boggs Holdings, near Pencaitland, and Wallyford Minersrsquo Institute.Located on the old brickworks site, Wallyford Industrial Estate was established by East Lothian District Council and is now run by East Lothian Council.Mr Cranston, from Jedburgh, was interested to hear about the Wallyford discovery, saying it was likely that lsquoEdinburghrsquo brick was made at Wallyfordrsquos brickworks.He said the lsquoPrestongrangersquo brick would have been made at Prestongrange at Prestonpans, which produced bricks from the s until . Niddrie also had a brickworks and the GISCOL bricks would have been manufactured in one of its many brickworks across the Central Belt.Mr Cranston, who is hoping to establish a museum dedicated to the brickmaking industry, appealed to people who discovered bricks or had other information relating to bricks to contact him via facebook scottishbrickhistory or his website scottishbrickhistoryAlister Hadden, chairman of Wallyford Community Council, said: ldquoIt is so nice to uncover a little of Wallyfordrsquos industrial heritage with this find of local bricks.ldquoThe brickworks gave employment not only to many in the village but to the surrounding area for a period of nearly  years.

title: army-stop-off-help-day-centre-staff-delivering-lunches
story: Members of the  Provost Company, part of the st Regiment Royal Military Police and based in Livingston and Stockton-on-Tees, helped deliver the lunches to members of the day centre last month, helping out those who have been shielding during the coronavirus lockdown.They also spoke to day centre members on their doorsteps.Some members askedthey could go for a ride in the military police car but sadly that was not possible due to the current restrictions.The members of the army unit are willing to make regular visits to the centre and, when it can get back to normal, pay a visit.The army visit came about as centre manager Margaret Mackrsquos husband Sandy works in the military in Edinburgh.Sandy then suggested that the visit would be a good thing to be involved in and arranged for some personnel to be sent across.The visit is said to have made a big dference to residents.Gullane Day Centre closed its doors to visitors, volunteers and service users on March .It has since been running a reduced service and has aimed to keep in touch with as many users and volunteers as possible.Staff have continued to work hard on reduced hours to adhere to social distancing.They have delivered meals, spoken to people by phone and stayed in touch with the centrersquos users and volunteers.Activities, such as jigsaws, quizzes, music, books and puzzles, have also been delivered.Some users of the centre are isolating without any help, so staff have been helping them complete their weekly food shop.People are being encouraged to contact Gullane Day Centrethey would like to talk to staff.Margaret told the Courier that she did not know when the day centre would be able to reopen but said that she hoped to work on plans so it could open as soon as it was safe to do so.She added: ldquoWe know everyone is missing attending the centre.ldquoWe would like to thank everyone who has supported us.Kenneth Wright, chairman at Gullane Day Centre, said: ldquoI would like to show appreciation for all the special efforts being made by our staff to keep deliveries and support for the members who are housebound.#ldquoI would like to add my appreciation to all our staff who are continuing to deliver hot meals and support to our members who have been housebound.ldquoOur team have achieved sterling work under the guidance of our centre manager.

title: community-praised-racing-returns-musselburgh-racecourse
story: Musselburgh Racecourse saw racing resume behind closed doors at two events at the start of the month and held a third event recently.The move involved introducing security measures around the course, which is on Common Good land, to protect the public, racecourse staff and visitingjockeys.The land on which the racecourse operates is a popular walking spot for locals and dog walkers,with neighbouring lagoons.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said the course had received huge support from local residents as it sought to ensure fixtures could be held safely and meet health and safety standards.Ahead of the inaugural meeting, the racecourse put in place a lsquoGreen Zonersquo which ensured admission to the grounds was controlled and monitored to minimise the risk posed by Covid-.Safety barriers were erected at points around the course on Linkfield Road and stewards advised local residents where to access the course without encroaching on the Green Zone.Other measures included all attendees completing a compulsory Covid- education module, an online health questionnaire, providing personal details and photo ID, and on arrival undergoing temperature checks by qualied medical staff.Mr Farnsworth said the protocols had been agreed in advance with East Lothian Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Groupand the British Horseracing Authority in order to meet safety guidelines introduced by the Scottish Government.He said: ldquoWe understand the new procedures may have caused some inconvenience to local residents and we will refine the process when Covid- regulations are relaxed.ldquoWe do appreciate the continued support of the local community in bringing racing back to Musselburgh.ldquoThe purpose of the controlled measures is to ensure the safety of the participants on each race day and the safety of the local community, and we are acting on feedback received from local residents following the first two meetings.ldquoWe have placed additional signage on Linkfield Road to ensure the public who use the links and lagoons for recreation and dog walking are fully aware of the access areas during future race days.ldquoOur aim is to provide as much public access to the grounds surrounding the racecourse as possible, whilst operating a safe sporting event.

title: runner-makes-record-time-john-muir-way
story: James Stewart pulled on his running shoes on Friday, July , in Helensburgh and ran through the day and night to reach the finishing line on Dunbar High Street the next morning!The -mile route was opened in  by then First Minister Alex Salmond.On July , the five-mile limit for leisure travel was lted and James, from Croy in North Lanarkshire, set off for the start line.Leaving at am, he powered through torrential rain, which meant changes of footwear, to reach Dunbar at .am on Saturday.James was pleased to complete the route in  hours and  minutes and told the Courier he had been confident in completing it under  hours.He said: ldquoAt the end of the day, there are a couple of reasons why I was confident I could set the fastest known time.ldquoI know the guy who did it previously and I ran with him for a bit. He knew I was going to go for it and I was always confident I could do it under  hours because my  hoursrsquo personal best is  miles on a running track.ldquoThere is still a lot that can go wrong and you have got to keep moving. You never know when you are going to feel ill or turn an ankle and need to walk  miles, which can slow you down for an hour or two.The -year-old was aware of the route, which passes through Croy, before taking on the challenge.However, he did not do any ldquorecce on any of the  sections of the -kilometre route that he was unfamiliar with.Instead, armed with a head torch, he ran through the night to reach Dunbar.And, although the weather was wet in the west, he was rewarded for his efforts as he came into East Lothian.James, who works for Sky, said: ldquoWe had a stunning sunset going through Edinburgh.ldquoAs I came off Corstorphine Hill, I was dropping down into Brunstane and Musselburgh and at that point I was getting a really stunning sunset and knew I was going to get a great sunrise.ldquoIt was maybe dark for five hours and the sunrise as I came through the coast was incredible. The best bit of it was the sunrise over North Berwick Law.James was greeted by a welcoming party on Dunbar High Street shortly before am.Duncan Smeed, chair of John Muir Birthplace Charitable Trust, was on hand to present an IOU for a certicate to show he had completed the route.He said: ldquoI wanted to make sure somebody from the Birthplace was there to welcome him, even though we cannot open the Birthplace just yet.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. The whole experience was really good. They had some great chats with Mary.ldquoMartin and Roman were so nice and made us feel very at ease.ldquoI was more of a Duran Duran fan but I didnrsquot tell him that!ldquoItrsquos nice that they are recognising kids that have done something that wee bit dferent.ldquoIt was also nice to see what it takes to film a TV show and how it is all done ndash Roman fluffed his lines a couple of times. It was an honour and a privilege to have had the opportunity from ITV.Ahead of watching the show, Karen admitted she was nervous.However, afterwards she described it as ldquoone of the most surreal experiences and said she was really pleased with how the show turned out.She said that both Mary and Abbie also loved filming the show.She added a thanks to Mary for doing her TikTok challenge, which raised more than pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.

title: five-year-old-poppys-helping-hand-east-lothian-foodbank
story: Poppy Fulton was inspired to help East Lothian Foodbank after hearing her mum and dad, Ashley and Richard, talking about food parcels.The conversation spurred Poppy into walking with her mum from her home in Athelstaneford to Haddington at the end of last month ndash just days after she turned five.Her proud mum was delighted to say that the fundraiser had collected more than pound, for the Tranent-based good cause.She said: ldquoThe whole way round the walk, she was raring to go.ldquoI was expecting a little bit of resistance and to coax her at some points.ldquoShe got to the end and started to cry when she saw everybody cheering for her.ldquoShe is quite excited to go in and visit the foodbank.ldquoI cannot quite believe how many people have donated.As well as financial donations, supermarket giant Morrisons also got involved and donated several bags of food, which have also gone to the foodbank.Before the walk, Ashley, who works as a teacher at Royal High School in Edinburgh, and her husband, who works with City of Edinburgh Council in homeless prevention for young people, were talking about food parcels being delivered to people in need.Ashley said: ldquoPoppy asked why they would need to do that and we were explaining some people did not have food.ldquoShe was getting really upset and asking why and she could not understand why some people did not have food.ldquoShe was getting more upset and she said that we had to help them.ldquoWe set a target of pound and Poppy wanted to do a bake sale but we said we could not really do that just now.ldquoWe told her some people did a sponsored walk and she said: lsquoWe will do that.rsquoldquoShe hates walking so that was quite a big thing to do.ldquoShe drew her own wee poster with a picture of me and her walking and some food around it and started telling everybody she was going to do it.Originally, mum and daughter were planning to cover the -kilometre distance on Monday, June .However, torrential rain saw the walk pushed back  hours, with Ashley and Poppy setting off shortly after am the following day.Grandparents came out to show their support as the little fundraiser made her way towards Haddingtonrsquos Market Street and the finish line.Ashley also revealed her daughterrsquos enthusiasm for the challenge was such that they had to stop off on the townrsquos Riverside Drive ndash where she did cartwheels ndash to ensure the welcoming party were in place in the town centre.To support the youngster, go to www.justgiving fundraising Poppy-Fulton

title: yummikeys-enjoy-tasty-profit-lockdown
story: Elspeth Fawcett, who lives in Aberlady, founded Yummikeys, a company that produces stainless steel sensory toys for babies, in .Since lockdown began in March, monthly sales of her toys have trebled.The mum-of-three said: ldquoMy business is fairly well established online, and, although the nationrsquos spending on the whole has probably decreased over the past few months, people are spending more time online, babies are still being born, mothers are still breast feeding and teething is simply part of le.ldquoAs more millennials become parents, I thinktrendstowards increasing eco-awareness and companies seen to be vocallyin-line with this will do well.She added: ldquoHaving already sold over , this year and with plans to get to , by the end of , we are excited at the prospect of freeing up ,kg of single-use plastic.For more information, visit yummikeys

title: dementia-friendly-walks-win-accreditation-project
story: Ageing Well, run by East Lothian Council in partnership with NHS Lothian, has been organising walks in Dunbar for dementia sufferers during the past year in a bid to reach the benchmark set by Scotlandrsquos walking charity Paths for All.Parvine Jazayeri, Ageing Well coordinator, undertook the necessary training and, in turn, was able to train volunteer leaders to lead the dementia-friendly walks, which took place on Fridays prior to the Covid- pandemic.She consulted with DF groups and worked closely with new partners such as Alzheimer Scotland.A portfolio showcasing the initiative was created and sent to Paths for All, which awarded Ageing Well the accreditation for Dementia FriendlyWalking, which could be rolled out across East Lothian subject to volunteer training.Parvine, who is based at Meadowmill Sports Centre, near Tranent, said: ldquoOver the past year, Ageing Well has been working very hard on the new project. We already run  health walks in East Lothian.ldquoTo make our walks even more inclusive, we wanted to ensure everyone and anyone could access them.ldquoWe have now been awarded our accreditation. This is such a great achievement for the Ageing Well project.She added: ldquoThe accreditation is a way of recognising the work of the Walking for Health projects that have made changes to support people, who are living well in the community with dementia, to engage in walking. The DF project team at Paths For All gave guidance and support to me throughout the year. The walks can now be classed as DF and will be continuing once this crisis has passed.ldquoI just want to say a massive thank you to everyone who has supported this project, especially the walk leaders. We could not have done this without them.ldquoIt has been a busy year but the hard work has paid off.ldquoAlthough our health walks may not be operating at the moment, I hope people are able to find some time to enjoy a walk close to home.Parvine said it was also hoped to introduce health walks for East Lothian residents with cancer as part of the Macmillan Move More Scotland programme after the Covid- crisis.She has also been working in partnership with CHANGES, a Musselburgh-based community health project, as the two organisations run similar walking programmes.They are hoping to launch dementia-friendly buddy walks across the county in the future. These would offer people who donrsquot like the thought of walking in a big group another option.

title: 5-000-raised-annual-christian-aid-collection
story: Christian Aid Week, which took place in May, saw Haddingtonrsquos churches coming together in a bid to raise money for the global charity.However, where usually that would mean door-to-door collections, the collectors were faced with a new challenge as coronavirus restrictions saw the campaign move online.John Weierter, from Haddingtonrsquos Christian Aid group, said: ldquoNationally Christian Aid built an interactive site with streamed worship and ious other activities.ldquoLocally we set up a JustGiving page for the Haddington churches and made arrangements to receive cheques posted directly to Janet Chrystal of St Maryrsquos, or to Graham Coe of the West Church.ldquoWe then had to wait with bated breath for our faithful supporters to come to us instead of us going out to them."We neednrsquot have worried ndash pound, in cheques cash was sent to our local collectors, pound, was raised via our JustGiving page and we received an incredibly generous cheque for pound, from the Church of Christ in Haddington, who had sold their buildings and were dispersing their funds."They requested the money be used lsquoto help the poor and preach the Gospelrsquo and this is surely what will happen.That took the total to pound,.The grouprsquos JustGiving page remains open until tomorrowand can be accessed via justgiving fundraising haddingtonchurchescagroup

title: airbnbs-scotland-seven-weird-wonderful-staycation-ideas
story: Our tourism industry officially opened its door again on Wednesday, with the First Minister encouraging people desperate for a holidayto explore more of Scotland rather than taking trips abroad.With that in mind, we thought wed gather together some of AirBnBs most bizarre and beautul listings in Scotland, to help inspire you ahead of your trip.From living in a futuristic airship, to taking up home in a hobbit-hole or even a leboat - here are sevenof the weird and wonderful AirBnB offerings in Scotland:AirShip - Drimnin, HighlandsAirBnBDescribed as an "iconic, insulated alumium pod, the AirShip is a one bedroom, one bathroom pod for a maximum of two adults.Situated in Drimnin in the Highlands, the listing has views of the isle of Mull from its "dragonfly windows".AirBnBThe "comfortable, quirky and cool" site is a perfect getaway - title: five-instagram-worthy-views-scotland
story: After months of uncertainty during the coronavirus lockdown, our countrys hotels, pubs, restaurants and other sectors reopen - with the virus suppressed to low levels acoss Scotland.To mark the news, weve pulled together five of the best on a range of topics.Here arefive of the best views in Scotland:Scottrsquos View, The BordersTake the B road from St Boswells to Kelso, following the signs for Dryburgh Abbey, and then turn onto the B to reach what is said to be Sir Walter Scottrsquos favourite view.A panorama of the River Tweed and the Eildon Hills, the latter a volcanic remnant that was once both home to ancient Romans and Iron Age people, itrsquos a vision that offers an impressive welcome to Scotland.However, Pete Irvine, of Scotland the Best fame, maintains that there is a better view across the road and up the hill, one that takes in the ldquofull panorama from the Cheviots to the Lammermuirs.You could always take in both, of course.Queenrsquos View, PerthshireHead along the B westwards from Pitlochry to get to the Queenrsquos View, which offers an impressive vista of Loch Tummel and beyond to Schiehallion.Queen Victoria was a fan, although, despite what she believed, informed sources suggest the viewpoint is, in fact, named not after her, but for Isabella, the first we of Robert the Bruce." alt"East Lothian Courier: Queens View " class"editor-image"Queens View In any case, you donrsquot have to be a royal to enjoy the panorama, and, as it is located on the eastern edge of the Tay Forest park, there are plenty of woodland walks to enjoy once yoursquove had enough of the visual splendour.Dunnet Head, CaithnessJohn OrsquoGroats might get all the attention, but Dunnet Head, at the end of the B, is the most northernmost point of mainland Scotland.As an added bonus, it has its own lighthouse and plenty of opportunities for birdwatchers as its part of a RSPB reserve.Weather permitting, you can look out to Stroma, Hoy and the Orkney mainland on a good day.And the sea clfs arenrsquot bad either. The nearby Castle of Mey is closed until the end of July as it stands. Worth checking when it opens before you make the journey perhaps.Glen Docherty, Wester RossFrom Inverness, head towards Kinlochewe on the A. About a mile and a half before you reach the latter, on the right-hand side, you can look out over the road ahead as it winds towards the freshwater Loch Maree glittering in the distance.Glen DochertyNamed after the Irish saint Mael Ruba, who travelled to Scotland in the seventh century, the loch is framed by the Torridon Hills and Slioch, and contains more than  islands.Cairnpapple Hill, Bathgate HillsYes, yes, yes, these are our mountains, and these are our glens, etc, etc. All very nice. But the marks we humans make on the landscape are worth our attention too.And so, as well as the Forth Valley, the Ochils and the Pentlands, the view east from Cairnpapple Hill takes in the Forth Bridges and the Grangemouth refinery." alt"East Lothian Courier: Cairnpapple Hill, Bathgate Hills " class"editor-image"Cairnpapple Hill, Bathgate Hills Not all pretty, then. But the hill was the site of a Neolithic henge, which means that from here you can effectively view the story of Scotland from ancient times to its post-industrial present.And afterwards you can pop back down into Linlithgow and enjoy its great cafes and its fantastic book shop, Far From the Madding Crowd.NB, Cairnpapple Hill is run by Historic Scotland so check it has been reopened before travelling.

title: five-beautiful-beaches-wont-believe-scotland
story: After months of uncertainty during thecoronaviruslockdown, our countrys hotels, pubs, restaurants and other sectors reopen - with the virus suppressed to low levels acoss Scotland.To mark the news, weve pulled together five of the best on a range of topics.Here arefive of the best beachesin Scotland:Ord beach, Sleat, SkyeOn the west of the Sleat peninsula with views across Loch Eishort to the Cuillin beyond, the sandy and pebble-strewn beach at Ord is a hub for wildle with otters, seals and eagles ndash white-tailed and golden ndash spotted here.Therersquos rarely more than a handful of people around and when the tide goes out there are rockpools for guddling in as the sea air blows away the cobwebs.Itrsquos a wonderful nook to watch the sunset or enjoy stargazing on clear nights.Traigh Mhor, BarraThe topography unfurls revealing rugged clfs, sand dunes, marram grass, wildflower-sprinkled machair and a patchwork of crofts, until finally you see it: a bright turquoise lagoon and the white sands of the runway.Traigh Mhor on Barra is part of a working airport rather than a place for sunbathing or building sandcastles, home to the only scheduled beach landing in the world. Once the island safely reopens to tourism and visitors, it is a must-tick on any bucket list.Chanonry Point, Black IsleThis shingled beach on a narrow spit of land jutting out into the Moray Firth will delight nature lovers.Scotlands east coast is home to almost  bottlenose dolphins and here at Chanonry Point, between Fortrose and Rosemarkie on the Black Isle, is one of their favoured haunts.Even on a dreich and gloomy day, the heart soars watching the pod produce a thrilling show of acrobatics as they play and fish in the strong currents.Loch Morlich, CairngormsScotlandrsquos only freshwater beach lies on the shores of Loch Morlich, surrounded by forest and against a backdrop of the Cairngorms.The sandy bay is popular for sailing, windsurfing, paddle boarding, kayaking and canoeing. Or you can just sit back and soak in the breathtakingly beautul scenery.Loch Morlich is the highest beach in Britain at ftand has an interesting history, the area used as a commando training school during the Second World War.Belhaven Bay, near Dunbar, East LothianPart of the John Muir Country Park, the beach at Belhaven Bay is a majestic stretch of sand. Fringed by sheltered dunes, salt marsh and grasslands, it looks out over the Forth Estuary with stunning views of the Bass Rock.Belhaven Bay is an easy-on-the eye spot for picnics. When the wind is up, it is perfect for activities such as beginner-friendly surfing or kite flying.Those keen to stretch their legs can take an amble along the nearby clf top trail towards Dunbar harbour.

title: museum-flight-plans-back-historic-environment-scotland
story: The public body which is tasked with protecting Scotlandrsquos heritage has backed the planned centre, which was refused planning permission by East Lothian Council over plans to cut down  trees of an ancient woodland.National Museums of Scotland has appealed to Scottish Ministers to overturn the local authorityrsquos decision, which came after thousands of people signed an online petition demanding the trees be saved and just months after councillors declared a lsquoclimate emergencyrsquo.Councillors ruled the museumrsquos plans to chop down  trees, to clear a path so it could move its historic collection of planes from its current outdoor site at East Fortune into a newly built hangar, breached their Climate Change Strategy and threw out the plans at a meeting in February.Protestors told councillors that alternative sites for the new centre, which would avoid destroying the tree belt, had not been given proper consideration.They pointed to an area to the west of the original site, and proposed new land on the neighbouring Gilmerton Estate as a better location.Now Historic Environment Scotland , which has responsibility for the airfield which the original museum is built on as a scheduled monument, "likely consider objecting to the centre being placed on the western site.In a statement lodged with the appeal, HES said it had been in discussions with museum bosses for nearly  years over the new visitor centre.Despite making no comment on the plans when they came before East Lothian Council in February for a decision, HES said it supported the visitor centre proposals.And it said in : ldquoOne alternative option on the west side of the scheduled monument was noted as being potentially problematic."If presented with a similar options appraisal today, we would likely provide similar advice, that being that the construction of a large visitor facility near the end of one of the runways would likely impact on key views along that runway.ldquoWe would consider views along and from the runway of an airfield to be a key characteristic of the cultural signicance of the site, and proposals that impacted on these views would likely result in a negative impact.HES said that view had not changed and remained advice it would give applicants, and it said of the impact of  trees being destroyed and the centre built to the south of the scheduled monument: ldquoWe would not consider the trees of Sunnyside Strip to be directly related to the cultural signicance of the scheduled monument ndash they are visible, but do not relate to our understanding of the monument as a wartime airfield.East Lothian Council submitted a response to the appeal which said it would be willing to consider a new site to the west of the airfield.It said: ldquo East Lothian Council is not opposed to the proposal of a new hangar however, East Lothian Council is opposed to the proposed location.ldquoIf the applicant was able to provide an alternative location for the hangar which did not involve the felling of such a substantial number of treesthen East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee indicated they would be likely to consider the application more favourablyMuseum bosses have said that the new visitor centre will generate pound.million and support  jobs in East Lothian ndash an increase on   when it generated pound.million and supported  jobs.More than  objections to the appeal have been lodged with the Scottish Reporter.

title: margiotta-looking-expand-across-east-lothian
story: Applying for a change of name for the former Londis Aberlady Village Store and opening hours, an agent for the new owners revealed it was just the first of a number of new ventures planned for the county.Alistair Macdonald, representing JELCM Ltd, which took over the store, said that while the company name might be unfamiliar to East Lothian Licensing Board members, the new shop name would not be.He said: ldquoJELCM is a new company set up by the Margiotta family who are a well-known retail family in Edinburgh. The company name is, I believe, made up of the initials of the grandchildren as this is seen as a venture for future generations. This is their first venture out of Edinburgh and it is hoped it will be the first of several properties in East Lothian.The Margiotta family took over the village shop in April but had been operating under old licensing conditions.The application asked for permission to formally change the shop name, extend its opening hours from pm to pm at night, add hot food and coffee takeaway services and deliveries.The board was told that the previous owner had closed at pm every evening not because it was a condition of licensing but because he was ldquoa family man.Two objections were lodged from members of the public concerned about the later opening hours and noise however, it was argued issues raised could be dealt with by staff.Councillor Jane Henderson, board member, welcomed the arrival of Margiotta in the county.She said: ldquoI find it very exciting and welcome Margiotta coming to East Lothian and the investment they are making. I wish them well.The application was approved unanimously.

title: return-mot-tests-need-know
story: The Department for Transport has announced that MOT tests will be recommencing on August , bringing an end to the period of automatic exemption brought in to keep key workers on the move during the Covid- pandemic.And while up until that point, cars will still be eligible for a six-month extension, vehicles with MOTs due after August  will need to be tested.Heres what to check prior to getting your car tested...TYRESTyres are the main point of contact between a car and the road, so its not dficult to work out why theyre so important. An MOT test will check the general condition of a tyre as well as the amount of tread it has, so its important to give them a thorough looking over. Make sure theyre inflated to the correct pressure too.The legal minimum tyre tread depth in the UK is .mm throughout a continuous band in the middle of the tyre. Tread gauges are the best way to check the depth, but you can use a p piece too - put the coin into a groove and,the outer rim of the p piece is obscured the tyre has enough tread. If you can see the outer rim, its definitely time for some new rubber.NUMBER PLATEIt can be easy to forget to check the number plate, but its an area which is checked during the test. Ensure its the right colour and that its fully legible too. It must also be the right size, too.HEADLIGHTS AND INDICATORSHeadlights and indicators are crucial to remaining safe on the road, which is why theyre a key part of the MOT test. Ensure theyre all working, and dont forget to test the hazard lights too!BRAKE LIGHTSIf you want to let people know that youre slowing down, then brake lights are a key - and legal - must. One of the easiest ways to check them over is to reverse up to a reflective surface - such as a window or shiny garage door - then press the brake pedal and check in the rear-view mirror to ensure theyre working.SEATS AND SEAT BELTSFront seats should have a good range of motion, so slide them forward and back to make sure everything is moving freely and easily. Seat belts should be checked over properly too pull them in and out to check theyre operating correctly and give them a sharp tug as well to make sure that they react as they should doa crash were to occur.HORNWhile youre inside the car, test out the horn and make sure it works - this is something that testers will check straight away.SCREENWASHThe majority of the checks on this list are easy to work out, but checking the screenwash is something that many people forget to do. An MOT centre can fail a cartheres not enough screenwash in the bottle ndash so its crucial that you check to see its filled to the proper level.WINDSCREENAnd while were on the subject of being able to see out of a car properly, its a good time to check over the windscreen. Any damage larger than mm will result in a fail, so look out for any stone chips or cracks.WINDSCREEN WIPERSWhile youre checking over the windscreen, give the wipers a thorough look too. They should be able to effectively clear the screen, leaving no streaks or making a rubbing noise. If thats the case, replace them ndash its a two-minute job on the vast majority of cars.ENGINE FLUIDS AND LEVELSIts best to make sure your car has plenty of fuel in the tank before you put it into its MOT, and its possible that you could be turned away from the test centreit doesnt have enough petrol or diesel. The same goes for engine oil ndash so check the levels of this are correct too.

title: scotlands-school-return-child-psychologist-reveals-three-top-tips
story: Schools across the country are set to open from August , with scientic advice published by the Scottish Government last week saying pupils should not have to physically distance when they go back.Face coverings should not generally be needed but staff should stay two metres away from children and other staff where possible.Despite the welcome , a leading teaching union has warned ofthe emotional trauma for children ing to school after a prolonged period off, and said a phasedwould be lsquovitalrsquo for their wellbeing.Alison Murphy, Secretary of the Edinburgh Educational Institute of Scotland local association, said: ldquoChildren will need to be run through lsquoThis is where you wash your handsrsquo, lsquoThis is your bit of the playgroundrsquo, lsquoThis is how the one-way system worksrsquo and so on.ldquoYou wonrsquot be able to do that per cent of pupils are in the building on the first day.ldquoIt would be chaos - it wouldnrsquot be safe.ldquoAnd therersquos the emotional trauma - theyrsquove been away from school for months.ldquoAn adult who had been off work for four months would be entitled to a phasedand for good reasons.Schools have been closed as a result of the virusThe online tutoring service MyTutor has enlisted the advice ofDr. Shreena Ghelani ndash a senior clinical psychologist ndash about how to handle theto school.Here are her three tips:Managing worry and anxietyIf you know your child might struggle with going back to school, try developing a mental toolbox of things they can do when they are worried at school.This might include a song to sing to themselves, visualising a calm place, practising breathing techniques and identying safe staff they can tellthey begin to feel nervous during the day.Speak to your children about the impact of CoronavirusLet children know that it is likely that other families may have been impacted by the virus,whether thatrsquos keyworking parents working hard, or family bereavements.Encourage your child to be patient and kindto other children.Let you child know what they might still be expected to do ndash not hug friends, wash their hands more often, or not share toys.Donrsquot rush to get back to normal too quicklyWhen school restarts in your area, you may find that children are more tired than usual by the extra demands and sensory stimulation placed on them.Ease them back in to their routine gently and allow enough space and time in a new schedule for any hiccups so that yoursquore not having to manage too many demands.When the time comes, yoursquoll find yoursquoll feel less stressedyou know there will be bumps in the road.You can find more tips and online tutoring at MyTutor.

title: plans-parking-north-berwicks-elcho-green-put-hold
story: East Lothian Council announced several temporary changes to the town centre last week as part of its lsquoSpaces for Peoplersquo initiative, which aims to revive towns while helping people socially distance to prevent the spread of coronavirus.Among the changes was the temporary creation of long-stay car parking spaces on North Berwicks famous Elcho Green, which overlooks the iconic West Bay.The announcement of the plans for the car park has outraged many residents in the town, who have shared their objections through a petition set up on Saturday evening in opposition to the plans. It has received nearly , signatures so far.This afternoon , East Lothian Council has stated that the plans for Elcho Green have been put on hold so that consultation can take place.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has successfully implemented a number of physical distancing measures on North Berwick High Street to support the need for safe access to the town centre and economic recovery."A further support for Spaces for People was a proposal to utilise a small part of Elcho Green in North Berwick as a temporary car park."The recovery from the Covid- pandemic is at a fragile point and there is a signicant risk of further infection spikes and a second wave it is therefore essential that we use the Spaces for People grant to enhance the safety and protect our communities."Elcho Green provides a temporary car park solution that replaces the loss of spaces on High Street and augments through the provision of a maximum of  spaces."The benefit of this would have been a reduction in the number of vehicles circling and queuing for parking spaces, enhanced safety for pedestrians and cyclists within the town centre and improved air quality."Equally, we are aware of the risk from visitors of displacement of parking throughout North Berwick and as a local authority, we have limited power to manage such risk. For these reasons Elcho Green could provide a temporary solution benefitting both local residents and visitors."East Lothian Council is a listening authority and we are aware of the ious perspectives being raised within the North Berwick community."As such, we intend to place the Elcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult."This delay will also enable us to monitor the impact of increased traffic as a result of visitors and to assess the effectiveness of measures introduced."We have seen in recent weeks, with the gradual easing of restrictions, large numbers of visitors coming to the East Lothian coast, towns and villages. North Berwick offers a unique environment and itrsquos a fine balancing act accommodating the ied needs of visitors, residents and businesses with necessary public health measures at this time and wersquoll continue to engage with key stakeholders regarding Spaces for People."North Berwick Coastal ward councillor Jeremy Findlay welcomed the news.He said: "I am very pleased that the council has listened to the views of residents of North Berwick and Elcho Green is not going to be turned into a car park."I hope the council, residents of North Berwick and councillors all now get together and come up with a solution that keeps everyone happy."Earlier, East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill had said that he and his SNP colleagues on East Lothian Council would be "making our opposition clear" to the plans.The councils decision to put the Elcho Green plans on hold comes two weeks after the local authoritys u-turn on Spaces for People plans in East Lothians other towns, after they were faced with a backlash from concerned traders and residents.Meanwhile, last week the council also put controversial plans for a transport hub at Whittingehame Drive in Haddington on hold, saying it instead wanted to focus on supporting the local economy in recovering from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: section-edinburgh-city-bypass-close-tonight
