title: mum-says-i-literally-begging-people-save-life
story: Trudie Murphy is hoping to fly out to the USA for treatment which could see the tumour removed.She was given the horrible news last week that specialists in Scotland would be unable to remove the cancerous tumour, while chemotherapy was also not an option.Doctors have said that she could receive radiotherapy but it would be as a last resort to extend her le.Now, a close friend, Colin Rillie-Caldwell, has launched an online appeal looking to raise more than pound,, which would be used to cover the cost of treatment.Trudie, who works part-time in Tranentrsquos Asda store, admitted to the Courier she was ldquopessimistic but would love the money to be raised to give her extra time with her children.She said: ldquoI would love to see it happen, to be able to be around for my kids ndash that is my sole driving force.ldquoThis GoFundMe page, I feel embarrassed because I feel like it is begging but I thought: lsquoI am literally begging for people to save my le so that I am here for my kids.rsquoldquoRight now, I just feel like somebody has put a plastic bag over my head and is slowly tightening it and I cannot breathe.ldquoIt is the last thing you think about at night and the first thing you think about in the morning.ldquoYou automatically think you would have it removed and have chemotherapy but to be told that you cannot, that they will not go in and do anythinghellipThe Tranent mum had been referred to hospital for brain and spinal MRIs after it was thought she had MS .However, the scans showed it was worse than first thought, with Trudie, who is mum to Joshand Naomi , who attend Ross High School, Zak , who will be starting at Knox Academy Meadowpark, and eight-year-old Archie, who attends Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, in Tranent, saying she ldquofelt numb after being told she had an inoperable brain tumour.A biopsy and chemotherapy have both been ruled out by experts due to the location of the tumour.She said: ldquoThey donrsquot know how aggressive it is because they cannot do the biopsy.ldquoThey were throwing everything at me ndash there are  types of brain cancer. They donrsquot know how quick it is going to grow.ldquoIrsquove been told I will start to have epileptic fits, I will lose my mobility and even simple things like swallowing I will be unable to do.With options on the NHS limited, Trudie and her husband Dave, who tied the knot  months ago, are looking at the possibility of travelling to America or other countries for treatment.Trudie, who has lived in Tranent for about eight years after previously living in Musselburgh, where she attended the townrsquos secondary school, said a hospital in America could use a needle ldquoas thin as a hair to take a biopsy, while the possibility of operating on the tumour had not been ruled out.Unfortunately, that would mean raising thousands of pounds to cover expensive medical bills.Friends and family rallied round for the online appeal, with more than pound, already raised.Trudie, , encouraged people to get in touch with raffle prizes for a future fundraiser and said: ldquoPeople can surprise you.ldquoIt is not always the people you are closest to that reach out but people I have not spoken to for a while that reach out to you."There are strangers I have never met that are donating money to somebody that they donrsquot know, especially just now because of lockdown.ldquoEverybody has been affected by this financially one way or another and I certainly did not expect to get over pound,.Dave, who works as a residential childcare worker in Ormiston, described the news as ldquodevastating.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to put it into words."She is so young, has so much to give and has so much to look forward to for this to potentially take her away, knowing potentially that something can be done ndash there are no words.To support Trudie, go to gofundme f treatment-for-trudie

title: plans-car-park-elcho-green-shelved
story: Councillors and council officials have this week been inundated with angry comments from disbelieving residents, protesting against cherished recreational area Elcho Green, at North Berwickrsquos West Bay, being utilised for an -space long-stay car park.The local authority said in a statement last Tuesday that, as part of ious measures inNorth Berwick to provide extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-, including widening pavements at the east end of High Street, it would be ldquoconverting part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.It stated that ldquofollowing a meeting with local traders, North Berwick CommunityCouncil and North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, agreement has been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town ndash but both the community council and area partnership told the Courier they had not given backing to the Elcho Green changes.The councilrsquos own timetable had Elcho Green car park opening last Friday .An online petition, West Bay not Parking Bay, to ldquoprotect stunning and iconic West Bay in North Berwick, was launched by resident Sarah Russell and had attracted more than , signatures in less than a week.It said: ldquoEast Lothian Council have announced plans to turn Elcho Green into a longstay car park.ldquoWhilst the council state that this is a temporary measure to comply with their Covid Spaces for People initiative, it is greatly feared that this will, in fact, lead to a permanent car park in the most iconic seafront location in East Lothian."North Berwick residents and visitors alike will be robbed of the very essence of this beautul recreational space that personies this famous conservation area seafront.ldquoTemporary or otherwise, Elcho Green is not the correct location for any car parking and we would urge you to help us stop this environmental catastrophe.Among those supporting the campaign was world-famous golfer and North Berwick resident Catriona Matthew, captain of Europersquos winning Solheim Cup team.The Courier has been swamped with letters and emails against the plans .The scheme was described as ldquoindefensible and ldquoundemocratic vandalism by some residents, while many asked why there had not been specic consultation on the plan and highlighted that the land had been gted to the town by the late Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple for recreational use in .On Monday, East Lothian Council released a statement that it was placing the ldquoElcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult.It is the second time in a month that the councilrsquos plans to transform town centres have hit the buffers.Earlier in July, proposals to suspend parking in town centres were put ldquoon hold after traders and residents in Haddington reacted with anger as cones and parking suspension signs were put up overnight, sparking widespread concern.In Mondayrsquos statement, Councillor Norman Hampshire , environment spokesperson, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has successfully implemented a number of physical distancing measures on North Berwick High Street to support the need for safe access to the town centre and economic recovery.ldquoA further support for Spaces for People was a proposal to utilise a small part of Elcho Green in North Berwick as a temporary car park.ldquoThe benefit of this would have been a reduction in the number of vehicles circling and queuing for parking spaces, enhanced safety for pedestrians and cyclists within the town centre, and improved air quality.ldquoEast Lothian Council is a listening authority and we are aware of the ious perspectives being raised within the North Berwick community.ldquoAs such, we intend to place the Elcho Green temporary car parking proposal on hold to allow us a further opportunity to engage and consult."This delay will also enable us to monitor the impact of increased traffic as a result of visitors and to assess the effectiveness of measures introduced.Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, said that recent u-turns were down to a ldquolack of political leadership within the Labour administration.He said he received more than  emails objecting to the Elcho Green plans.He called for a report on the Spaces for People plans, and in particular parking proposals in North Berwick, to be put before a meeting of elected council group leaders in two weeksrsquo time for approval.Under emergency Covid- procedures, normal council business is currently suspended and decisions are taken at monthly meetings of the group leaders and council chief executive.He said: ldquoThe decision must be approved by councillors at the leadersrsquo group meeting and it should be open and transparent and open to the press.Mr Hampshire accused Mr Currie of ldquoplaying politics in ldquoan emergency situation.ldquoWe have allowed him to take part in the meetings with officers at every point during the discussions, said Mr Hampshire.ldquoI have got to say the Conservative Group have been fully behind what we are doing."For the SNP to try to play politics in a situation where their own Government is instructing local authorities to create spaces in town centres is unbelievable.Conservative councillor Craig Hoy called on the administration to ldquotake notice of the recent problems caused by parking proposals.He said the Scottish Government had failed to give councils enough time to push through emergency Covid measures in town centres.Councillor Hoy said: "Scottish Councils are operating under huge pressure with limited resources, but that does not remove the need for them to consult fully and communicate clearly on big issues which impact our communities."I hope East Lothian Council and the Labour administration will take notice of the recent problems in North Berwick and fully engage with stakeholders."Hilary Smith, chair of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership, stressed that the area partnership had not attended any meeting regarding Covid- plans for the town or given its approval to the plans.North Berwick Community Council said it had not discussed Elcho Green prior to its meeting on Tuesday.East Lothian Council received pound.million from Scottish Government funding for Spaces for People projects to make social distancing easier in town centres and encourage people toto them safely.The council launched a consultation in May, asking people for their county-wide views.It attracted , contributions and more than  comments, including more than  from the North Berwick area.But North Berwick residents have not been asked their specic views on Elcho Green car parking.The council said it had given consideration to parking availability at a number of sites in North Berwick.In response to questions from the Courier, the council said: ldquoThe high school and sports centre are both due to re-open in coming weeks so were unsuitable to use.ldquoAn area of Elcho Green is considered suitable to take traffic arriving from the west to park for people visiting the town to intercept the flow of traffic and stop vehicles circulating through the town unnecessarily searching for parking spaces and generating additional traffic pollution.ldquoIt also seemed reasonable considering the area of land is used annually for Fringe by the Sea events."A maximum of  places had been identied for use as a potential temporary car park which is not part of the Spaces for People grant but provided as part of the programme.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-reopens-doors-today
story: The coronavirus pandemic forced the venue to close in mid-March but now preparations have been made and put in place for its reopening.The Seabird Centre, which is an independent charity, will open Thursday-Sunday, am-pm, in what it describes as a ldquohugely positive step.It will then close Monday-Wednesday to allow staff to review the visitor experience over the temporary opening time and make improvements where needed.Staff at the centre are ldquoreally excited to welcome people back and hope to be back to a daily am-pm opening from next Thursday .Several new processes are in place to help manage numbers and ensure everyone can visit safely, including a new booking system.The number of people allowed in at any one time will be signicantly reduced to about  per cent of normal capacity to allow for physical distancing.Because of this reduction, the Seabird Centre will only be able to earn a fraction of its usual income, meaning its future in the months ahead ldquoremains challenging.Having to suddenly close its doors in March due to Covid- had a ldquodevastating effect on the Seabird Centrersquos finances as it was forced to close at the beginning of the summer tourism season, something it relies on.In May it launched its first-ever urgent public appeal, which saw it aim to raise pound, and save it from permanent closure. title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: gardening-create-garden-getaway-feel-like-holiday
story: While many of us may be staycationing this year, there are ways to create a holiday haven in our gardens using plants and decor that mimic a host of exotic destinations.RHS Garden Wisleys exotic garden, for example, houses not only tropical-looking pineapple plants, striking palms and giant banana trees which flourish in summer, but shows what will survive the winter.RHS Wisleys garden manager Emma Allen, who looks after the exotic garden, says: "When experimenting with tropical plants at home, remember the right plant, right place rule. If you have a shady corner, make sure you plant shade tolerant options, andyou have sun trap areas, select plants that will flourish there."Allens top plants for a tropical sensation...Trachycarpus fortunei - a really hardy palm , this will give your garden the exotic look and feel without the need to worry about whether it will survive through winter. They are rather slow growing, ultimately reaching a height of over m after - years.Canna - any type of canna will bring large juicy leaves and exotic looking flowers in pink, orange, yellow, white or red. Some have iegated leaves such as Canna Stuttgart or Phaison.Passlora caerulea - a hardy semi-evergreen climber with the most striking flowers. This vigorous plant will cover a wall or pergola in no time.Fatsia japonica - a medium-sized evergreen shrub with palmately-lobed leaves to cm in width, and small white flowers in clusters and small black fruits.Dahlia - extravagant and flamboyant flowers, plus they flower all summer long. For drama and colour, try Karma Chocwith dark red velvety flowers, or Edwins Sunsetwith beautul vivid red flowers that almost glow.Use decor and accessories...Blend your tropical-looking plants with exotic accessories and seating to create a holiday feel. Experts at Dobbies Garden Centresoffer five design tips to help you into the holiday mood.... Go totally tropicalFill patio containers with a selection of vibrant bedding or perennial cottage garden plants for an instant display of foliage and flower colour, including Cordyline australis Peko, along with potted palms such as Phoenix canariensis, Chamaerops humilisand Trachycarpus fortunei to add height and interest and look great in groups. Position pots behind garden furniture to create the illusion that they are planted in the ground.. Create a colour popBring a brilliant burst of sunshine and add some zing to your exterior space using an eclectic array of brightly coloured pots, mixing and matching flowers in contrasting shades for maximum impact. Fun accessories will quickly brighten patios or balconies. Choose pots in vibrant primary colours, which will really pop against white or neutral backdrops.. Bring the indoors outBrighten your garden getaway by bringing houseplants outside for the day. Adding your favourite indoor orchid to a bistro table will create a tropical centrepiece - just be sure tothem to their normal home later on to ensure they dont get exposed to too much direct sunlight.An outdoor rug will instantly transform your space and offers protection to patios and decking from sun cream spillages or melting ice creams. They also help to zone an area, adding a stylish decorative touch. Day beds and hanging egg chairs are the ultimate garden getaway luxuryyou have room.. Make it magicalFor atmospheric evenings, accessorise with a iety of lanterns, fairy lights and candles to enhance the mood - it is amazing how magical a space can look at twilight. A stylish lantern, or a solar-powered string of lights draped across trees and fences will stretch out the time spent outside. Use blankets, floor cushions and chunky knit throws to keep warm and curl up under the stars.. And when the sun sets...Take the chill out of cooler evenings by investing in a practical chiminea or fire pit for your patio, adding warmth and light to extend outdoor entertaining.And think about how you are going to protect your plants during the cooler months, RHS expert Allen advises. "As many domestic gardeners do not have the time or space to bring plants inside over winter, it is essential to protect in situ. If focusing on the tropical look, select hardy options such as trachycarpus, fatsia, eucomis, tricyrtis, schefflera and zantedeschia, which will re-emerge after winter."If you want to have bananas or half-hardy palms, try wrapping them throughout the winter using horticultural fleece or hessian and fill the inside with straw for extra insulation," she adds.

title: books-richard-holloway-finding-spirituality-godless-world
story: Richard Holloway, the former Primus - or leader - of the Scottish Episcopal Church, may, however, have written a book which lays the first few paving stones on the path to finding some sort of spiritual meaning in a world in which God has long ago died.I had my last flash of believing in God when I was about seven. My grandmother was ill and I remember kneeling and praying at the foot of my bed for her. But even then, as a child, I knew what I was doing was ridiculous. I wouldnrsquot have understood the words ldquointerventionary God in , but I knew innately that there was no great being in the sky who was going to answer my prayers and make my grandmother better. Only science could do that.My grandmother lost her own faith after the death of her husband, but shersquod instilled in me a love for both the stories of the Bible and the poetry of it. By  Irsquod read the Bible from cover to cover. Reading it on your own - with no minister or priest to guide, or misguide, you - is perhaps the surest path to atheism. The biblical God is a monster, a Bronze Age psychopath, and the stories of the Bible are patently just that - stories. The Bible contains truth only in the way that a fairytale contains truth: therersquos wisdom and teaching there, not history or fact.The positive lesson I took from it was this:Jesus really existed then he was one of the most remarkable humans to ever live and we should all try to live by his teachings. He was no God, just a great and wise human being.I spent my twenties sneering at and hating religion. By my thirties, as I found myself growing into fatherhood, I realised that while I still had contempt for religion and faith, the lack of meaning in my le - beyond the love of my children and family - was starting to trouble me.By my forties I understood that while atheism is factually, historically, scientically the only game in town, theres something about the human mind that requires more than pure reason alone. Reason does not provide meaning. It merely explains.Reason tells me God doesnrsquot exist. But then what  Shopping, spending, consumption, gyms, acquiring more money, ambition, work, aimless travel, TV as an analgesic for the soul hellip drink, drugs, food, sex, endless bitter and dark cynicism  What replaces God in a world where God is dead  What holds the centre together Irsquove just turned , and, like most of the world amid the pandemic, my thoughts have been tinged with intimations of mortality these last few months. Then along comes this octogenarian from Glasgow called Richard Holloway and he offers a speck of hope.This is no self-help book, incidentally. This isnrsquot New Age hokum, rather the working out of a manrsquos soul,such a thing exists. Itrsquos the story of Hollowayrsquos intellectual le, its trials, its failings, and how he has come to find spiritual meaning free from the dictum of religion.I struggle to define this book - Stories We Tell Ourselves: Making Meaning in a Meaningless Universe - beyond saying that it represents a first step toward a new form of spiritual thought. Holloway, once one of our nationrsquos leading religious figures, is now ldquoa Christian without God. He does not believe in the fairytales of religion - and he especially distrusts the ldquoruthless optimism of priests and ministers, and the cost they have wrought to human happiness - but he holds the Christian message as close to his heart as any man or woman still wearing the cloth of God.ldquoI follow Jesus, he says in closing his book, ldquoetsi deus non daretur. Or to translate the Latin, ldquoasGod were not there. Science has consigned God to the grave, but we can still live the ideals of Christianity without buying into the ludicrous myths of Adam and Eve and Noahrsquos Ark.What Holloway does most powerfully is dismiss certainty in all its forms - political as well as religious. People have died for certainties, and killed for certainties, whether its how a person prays or how much power a political party has. Today, those certainties are seen rightly as ghastly jokes, absurd crimes, like the war Jonathan Swt satirically imagined in Gulliverrsquos Travels which raged between those who opened their boiled egg from the bottom or the top.We can be certain of nothing, Holloway tells us, but doubt and love. Wersquore surrounded by ldquoruthless optimists on all sides politically - leavers, remainers, Yes, No, left, right - on it goes - others demanding we see the world through their eyes only. Holloway says to hell with that. Nobody knows anything when it comes to the decisions which shape the future - wersquore all taking shots in the dark. What matters is that we acknowledge our limitations, take others into consideration when we make our choices and try to hold a sense of love in our hearts for every living creature.Holloway speaks of ldquoresolute irresolution, the necessity of holding two opposing ideas in onersquos head at the same moment - God may be dead but the message of the man called Christ matters. Most of all, he says, we must not ldquoclose our account with reality. In other words, we must never shut our minds, and think we have found the answers because we havenrsquot and never will.This is a gospel of love, and doubt, that everyone can practice - especially atheists. For that Irsquom truly grateful to Holloway for codying what Irsquove innately felt throughout my le. Itrsquos brought a flicker of light into a darkened world. Holloway brings a message of spiritual hope for all - and for that, a few hundred years ago, this very wise and very kind man would have been burned to death at the stake. That makes him a hero in my eyes, and so and I say, God bless him.

title: cork-people-proud-show
story: "I feel I can do anything in front of the crew, which we have - theres not much of me that the crew hasnt seen!" quips the Cork-born star, .In the BBC comedy, Murphy plays Conor MacSweeney, whos best friends with Jock OKeeffe, played by fellow Corkonian, Chris Walley, .Over the past two series - spin-offs from the  film of the same name - we have followed the two loveable rogues as they get themselves into all sorts of sticky situations.Particularly memorable storylines include the teenagers attempt to steal a giant tuna fish from the market in series one, and when they got expelled after stripping off in the classroom and peeing on Principal Walshs leg in series two.Now were getting a series three, in which we see the lads trying to make their way as young adults, with yet more questionable methods of making some money, all while Jock navigates being a new dad.One things for sure things wont go smoothly.Here, we chat to Walley and Murphy, plus Hilary Rose - who plays Conors stressed-out but loving mum, Mairead - to find out more.NEW CHAPTERIts an unconventional family set-up in The Young Offenders, which is set and filmed in Cork.A heart-warming episode in series one saw widower Maireadbecome a foster mum to Jock - whose mum is also dead - after he escapes his abusive, alcoholic dad.At the end of series two, Jocks girlfriend Siobhan - whose dad happens to be Principal Walsh, who is far from the biggest fan of Jock and Conor - gave birth to baby Star .The new addition to the family means Principal Walsh and his we Orla - whose other daughter Linda is going out with Conor - now have to engage more with Mairead, which hasnt always gone well in the past."Season three was interesting from a character point of view because Mairead really cuts loose and, at some stages, the lads are telling her to calm down!" follows Rose, whos also from Cork, and married Peter Foott - who created The Young Offenders - since .As for the love story between her and Sergeant Healy, she teases "season three kinda continues that on-again, off-again, will they, wont they vibe".The main storyline for series two is how Jock is adjusting to everyday le with baby Star."Conor and Jock are still getting into their sticky situations but now theres just a baby there as well," reveals Walley."I think its just a major sht in their lives and theyre just trying to figure it out all together."PARENTING LESSONSTwins Nola and Penny Richardson shared the role of Star, and Walley says the babies were "incredible"."I want one!" exclaims Murphy, before quickly adding "not right now".Rose chimes in at this point, saying she has told the boys they are always welcome to babysit her kids ."Theyre both amazing babysitters, but there was a time when Jake was very young where they bought him a nerf gun," she recalls, which sets them all off laughing, with her on-screen sons looking a little sheepish."I dunno, we were buying toys and we were like, This is what kids that age like!" reasons Walley."There was some force off ityou shot it," he concedes. "Theyre heavy-duty.""That was a real Conor and Jock moment for the two of us," admits Murphy.Having Penny and Nola on set this series was definitely a learning curve for the young actors."I was terried of holding babies for fear I dropped them," confides Walley. "By the end of the shoot, I just was inseparable."MEMORABLE MOMENTSAccording to Murphy, "theres not a street in Cork city that we havent filmed on"."The Cork people are so proud of the show."Having crowds watching them film was something they "had to get used to pretty quick.""There was a great photo in the paper a few years ago, of us making the film there are about  people in the crew, no-ones watching us filming," notes Murphy."And then there was a photo of us making season , and there were just crowds of people watching."It was good, it was like doing a play every day, whenever we were filming outside in the city."One of the new episodes sees Jock, Conor and Mairead take a trip to Dublin.Whilst filming on a road in the Irish capital city, they reveal they were pulled over by Leo Varadkars entourage as he was driving past them in an unmarked executive car.The Irish politician was taoiseach at the time ."There was a camera in the back seat, and we were mid-scene and we were like, What does this guy want  Were filming!" says Rose."And eventually Alex put down the passenger window and was like Hey!, and next thing Leo Varadkar leaned forward!""His driver was like, Great show!" recalls Murphy. "We were like, Do you like it [to Varadkar] And he went, I havent seen it!""But he did say, Ive heard its great", adds Rose.CHARACTER DEVELOPMENTThe biggest thing Rose has taken away from making The Young Offenders is the amazing relationships theyve formed with cast and crew ."Its about getting the job done and doing the best that you can, but you have to remember as well, for actors, were really vulnerable in front of all the crew, so you kinda put your trust in them," she elaborates."If were doing emotional scenes, theyre witnessing it, theyre trying to support you."As for future series, Murphy points out the only issue could be that he and Walley dont exactly look  anymore."At some points in the script, Jock will go, We cant do that, were only , and we were like, Can we just not mention our age " he continues, chuckling."As long as we look young, I guess well see what happens. CGI is working pretty good these days..."The Young Offenders is available on BBC iPlayer and on BBC One from Friday.

title: gardening-tvs-carol-klein-shares-top-picks-longer-lasting-summer-plants
story: Did you buy summer bedding plants months ago, when they first went on sale and panic-buying was all around If so, you might have noticed they look a little tired by now, after the baking sun we had in May followed by endless rain.But, how can you plug the gaps to bring colour into your garden thatll last until the autumn TVs Carol Klein will be offering late summer gardening inspiration to visitors of the virtual RHS Flower Show Tatton Park at Home on July , hosted on the RHS website."You should go for perennials, because not only will they look good right through the summer and into the autumn, but they will keep coming back every year. They are much more worth the investment. Its not worth planting bedding plants at this time of year," says the BBC Gardeners World regular.You can enjoy a riot of colour with late-summer flowering perennials in shades ranging from zingy yellows to scorching reds and burnt oranges, which will last into October."Theres a huge group of plants which are all from the States, but which we think of as common English cottage garden plants, flowering from mid-summer onwards," adds Klein.Here are some of her recommendations...ASTERS"Michaelmas daisies start flowering as we go into August but then they will go right the way through," she says. "Aster novi-belgii is a tough aster which never seems to get disease and is ideal."They can be planted in summer, where you have gaps left by early-flowering plants, and grow to around cm. They prefer sun or light shade and should be kept well watered in dry soils. They make good companions with other autumn-flowering plants, including Japanese anemones.HELENIUMS"These plants, which are vaguely from the daisy family, are superb. If you keep on deadheading, they will flower right up to the end of September," says Klein. "They are just starting to flower. My favourite is Helenium El Dorado, which produces great big golden flowers, and Sahins Early Flowerer. There are lots of traditional ones, including Moerheim Beauty with its dark, copper-red daisy-like flowers, which are also popular."When you deadhead, cut down to the next bud on the stem, which will then flower and you can get a show through to autumn. Lt and ide heleniums every few years, which will increase your stock, Klein adds."If you split them in the spring, they almost fall apart for you. We do that with ours, planting three little pieces at a time."RUDBECKIASRudbeckias, also known as coneflowers because their bright yellow petals hang down, emphasising the prominent dark central cone, are from the same group of North American daisies. "Rudbeckia fulgida deemii or Goldsturm are both beautul," Klein enthuses.Goldsturm has such an abundance of flowers that it has an almost solid effect in the late summer border. Use the smaller ieties with fiery displays of crocosmias and red hot pokers in a border, or put them in a pot to add patio colour, around perhaps a burgundy cordyline. Taller types can be put at the back of a border, framed by late-flowering clematis.PERENNIAL SUNFLOWERThese helianthus are not like the traditional big-flowered annual we know and love, but they do make a statement and come back year after year, says Klein."My favourite is Lemon Queen. Its a big plant but even in a little garden, you can have a big plant for impact, that will flower into October and occasionally even further."It grows to around m tall, with coarse, deep green foliage and light yellow flowers cm wide, with pale yellow ray florets and a dark yellow central disk.CROCOSMIASAlso known as montbretia, crocosmias are one of the main features at the RHS Tatton show. They may have a reputation for being a bit invasive, but you can just pull up the cormsthey outgrow their space, she says."Id put crocosmias with any of the plants weve just mentioned. I have Crocosmia Lucer, which has just started to flower and it is taking over from big euphorbias."MISCANTHUSDont just consider colour when youre filling the gaps, because grasses come into their own in summer and beyond. "Varieties like Miscanthus Flamingo are so useful because they look good now but they will have beautul plumes in September, and then you can leave them all winter for structure," says Klein.Many of these plants can be obtained from the nurseries who attend the RHS shows, including Bluebell Cottage Gardens , Morton Nursery , Daisy Roots , Hardys Cottage Garden Plantsand Burncoose Nurseries .For more late summer gardening inspiration, visit rhs.org.uk tattonathome

title: recipe-mary-continis-cream-chicken-soup
story: Come rain or shine, the beaches were packed from morning till night and our cafes and chip shops did a roaring trade. We started at  in the morning and didnrsquot lock up until  at night once the pubs had emptied and the revellers had staggered home with a poke of chipshelliprsquosalt and sauce!rsquo Those were the days!When the weather broke and the summer storms blew in, my mother, Gertrude Di Ciacca, made huge pots of soup to serve with a roll and butter to keep them warm. All home made, tasty and nutritious.This was my favourite, very delicious and much classier than opening a tin!CREAM OF CHICKEN SOUPIngredients: ml Chicken Stock made with  breast or  thighs  legs free range chicken,  sticks celery, stalks of parsley ml full fat milk fresh bay leaf shallotg unsalted butter tablespoons plain flourSea salt and ground white pepper tablespoons thick creamFlat leaf parsley finely choppedMethod:First, make the chicken stock by simmering the chicken in ml water with the celery and parsley stalks for an hour or so.Season with sea salt and set aside.To make the soup:Place the milk, bay leaf and shallot in a saucepan, bring to a slow simmer.Take off the heat and set aside to let the flavours infuse.Make a classic bechamel sauce.Melt the butter in a saucepan and add the flour.Stir on a low heat with a wooden spoon until the mixture forms a ball.Cook on a medium heat for about  minutes to cook the flour, turning it with the spoon and taking care not to let it burn.Now strain half of the infused milk into the saucepan and stir the mixture until you get a smooth white sauce. Donrsquot worrythere are lumps at the start. These will disappear as the mix heats up.Once the mix is smooth add the rest of the strained milk.Bring back to a simmer and cook for about  minutes.Season.Now, strain the cooled chicken stock into the mixture and heat everything again to simmering, stirring to make the soup.You can do all this in a blender.Check seasoning and serve with pieces of the cooked chicken, a swirl of cream and a sprinkling of chopped parsley.

title: Country Life with Rosemary Goring  The joys of a cottage garden
story: In the environs of Hoolet, other than the padlocked cast-iron gates of the great houses, there is no such thing as a private garden. In one sense, everyonersquos property is off limits without permission, as it is anywhere . Unless, that is, yoursquore an apple-scrumping child ndash and which of us has never been  At this stage of le a garden with fruit trees is excellent training for a career in the SAS ndash get in, achieve mission and scarper without trace or casualties. Part of the allure of these raids, as I recall, is not just the trepidation of trespassing, but of taking forbidden fruit. Usually we gathered the unripe apples and stone-hard pears as ammunition for our long-running battles, rather than as a source of vitamin C. If kids ever clamber over the fence for our apples, theyrsquod be more than welcome. If they could also pick the crab apples and turn them into jam that would be appreciated.Many aspects of le are very dferent this summer from last, but one thing has not changed. Regardless of the lurgy, fruit is ripening fast on bushes and trees the high season of berries is upon us. One of the most vivid memories of our first August here was sitting in a friendrsquos summerhouse and suddenly seeing three folk emerging from the far end of their garden. Each was clutching a bowl heaped with jewel-like fruits, and as they passed it was aswersquod glimpsed the three Magi.A few days ago, we were invited into the same garden, to help ourselves to raspberries. It had been a day of torrential rain, with intermittent sun. The sky was darkening as we made our way between the rows, which were heavy with fat sweet rasps. When the rain began, I put up my hood, and picked on. The scent of wet leaves and trodden earth was intoxicating, a bouquet richer than a Barola. These bushes had been growing here long before our friends arrived,  years ago. They are kept company by apple and pear trees, redcurrant bushes, and plums that, when ripe, hang from the branches like ear-rings. Therersquos also a large bed of still-ripening strawberries. One year I watched a mouse, on tiptoe, nibbling a dangling berry.Irsquove rarely tasted better raspberries than the ones we collected, their flavour enhanced by the atmosphere of the garden where they grew. Being allowed access to this most beautul, out of the way corner reminds me a little of The Secret Garden. That book that made such an impression on me as a girl that I drove my parents nuts begging to be allowed to buy a derelict Victorian walled garden close by. I would climb onto the seat by the bus stop to look over its wall and plan how Irsquod clear it of weeds and shattered glass house and fill it with vegetables and flowers. Since Irsquod shown no desire to lt so much as a dandelion in our own back yard, I was told to dream on.The garden where we, and others, are invited to forage is a perfect complement to the fields and hills beyond. Flowerbeds, graceful trees and a croquet-style lawn coexist seamlessly with fruit and, previously, rows of vegetables too. When people picture the rural idyll, itrsquos often a rose-festooned house where hollyhocks run amok. Yet the true cottage garden was never chocolate-box pretty but a place where leeks and cabbages grew among primroses and poppies ndash more Mr McGregor than Vita Sackville-West. That is still the case. In one of my favourite Hoolet gardens, a formal square bed of roses encloses a profusion of succulent young lettuces, ready to lt for lunch.This is an artful nod to where all such cultivation began. Originally, humble countryside plots were essential sources of food there was no room for unproductive and time-consuming grass, or patios where clematis and wisteria rambled towards dormer windows, choking the gutters. Wholly utilitarian, they contained rectangular beds devoted to cabbages and potatoes and, weather permitting, caned trellises for fruit. These were beautul in their own way, but it was only when flowers escaped from hedgerows and colonised the margins and spaces between the plots that they gained nostalgic postcard charm.The plant collector, Major Lawrence Johnston, is responsible for redefining the cottage garden. In the early th century, when he and his mother moved into Hidcote Manor in the Cotswolds, he took the idea of a rural plot, edited its contents, and scaled it up. The result, with winding paths, artistic focal points, and teeming, colourful borders, had the appearance of being haphazard, random and accidental, when in fact it was rigorously planned. It sounds spectacular. Increasingly, though, Irsquom coming to think that outdoor spaces designed solely to please the eye are lacking in one vital ingredient: the kind you can put on a plate.Thanks in part to the generosity of neighbours, we too are starting to feed ourselves: redcurrants and blackcurrants, strawberries ndash still in relative infancy ndash rhubarb, carrots and herbs. Wersquore not in the league of those who can nurture asparagus Irsquom told it takes seven years for a first crop to appear. In fact, wersquore not in any league at all. After Alan dug up last yearrsquos potatoes, I replanted that bed with roses, honeysuckle and lavender. At one point in late spring, these new arrivals were suddenly swamped by a profusion of shaws, as the undetected, button-sized potatoes left buried in the winter sprouted into le. Following a striking display of flowers, we now have an unexpected crop of delicious spuds to keep us going for weeks. The satisfaction of filling your own larder is immense. Itrsquos at times like this that you realise keeping a cottage garden is a process of give and take.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: midge-repellents-keep-biting-beasties-bay
story: The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .:Staycation nation:  unusual and quirky places to holiday in ScotlandThe midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.As many as half a million of these insects can hatch from a two-square-metre patch of suitably wet, peaty soil. This can equate to , trillion midges during the peak season. Im itchy just thinking about it.There are  species of midges in Scotland, but it is Culicoides impunctatus ndash aka the Highland Midge ndash which is responsible for the lions share of the biting. Found in the north and west of Scotland, it isnt shy about feasting on the blood of passing humans, pets, livestock and wildle.Argyll-based landscape artist John Lowrie Morrison has spoken about the surprising influence that midges have had on his work. Morrison ndash known as Jolomo ndash said that at one stage he resorted to smoking cigars while painting outdoors to ward them off.When this failed, he was driven indoors ndash a change in working practice which Morrison suggested enhanced his work as an expressive painter.Another to suffer is the former Doctor Who actor, Tom Baker, who has talked about battling the midges while filming the Highland-based drama Monarch of the Glen. "The midges adored me," he said. "They couldnt get enough of me. They ate me up."Fun fact: only female midges bite as the males feed off pollen and plant materials. The reason is that the females emerge with sufficient fat reserves to mature their first batch of eggs, requiring the rich nutrients gleaned from blood for any subsequent broods.If you have wondered why midges are drawn to humans, it is partly because they find the carbon dioxide in our breath irresistible. The solution  Stop breathing.:Scotland reopens: Our favourite views, picnic spots, drives, walks, hills, lochs and beachesMidges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy. Here we test some of the best midge-repelling lotions and potions.Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency: A dry oil spray.Smell: Baby talcum powder.Verdict: Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency: A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell: Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict: Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.Ingredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency: A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell: Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict: A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency: A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell: Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict: An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: herald-diary-make-creep-crawl-off
story: THE following story uses violent imagery, but then Shakespeare tended to chuck buckets of blood across the boards of the Globe Theatre. So wersquore in good company. Reader Laura OrsquoReilly was in a Glasgow pub where a creepy bloke was eyeballing a young woman from a distance. The bloke eventually swaggered over and, staring at the womanrsquos legs, grunted: ldquoNice pins, hen.The woman countered: ldquoIf a hud oany pins on me, Irsquod be jabbinrsquo them intae a voodoo doll orsquo you, pal.The vanquished suitor dissolved into the shadows, and probably hasnrsquot crept out of them since.Talking scentsMASKS. They donrsquot just cover up. They reveal things about ourselves. ldquoIt wasnrsquot until I wore a face mask shopping that I realised my breathrsquos honking, admits reader John Fraser.ldquoEither that or the armpit of a professional darts player keeps sneaking in there, next to my nose.Trump thatAS the first actor to play psycho psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter, Brian Cox relishes being a scary villain. Though some roles are too reprehensible, even for him. ldquoTrump is a bad part because the man has got no dimension, he says. ldquoHersquos a nitwit. A dumbass. The manrsquos a congenital idiot. If someone asked me to play Trump, Irsquod say no.If a blockbuster about The Donald is made, perhaps Cox would be willing to pull on a skirt and girdle to play Trumprsquos wee Scottish maw. The Dundonian is one of the few Hollywood high flyers who could pull off the accent without turning the movie into Brigadoon : The Wacko White House Years.Broken breakWE continue comparing the world before lockdown with present circumstances. Simon Cunningham offers the following.THEN: ldquoWhere shall we go on holiday  Floridarsquos nice, with the beach and Disney WorldhellipNOW: ldquoWhere shall we go on holiday  The top of Buchanan Streetrsquos a possibility. And therersquos a bench to sit on which is only a little damp in the rainhellipMonster mealA READER complained that hammocks are overrated. Sam Winward believes the same is true of a swanky lobster meal. ldquoThe vile crustaceans look like aliens from a s Doctor Who episode, winces Sam. ldquoTom Baker in a long scarf should be forking them. Not me.Age and wisdomGLASGOW-BASED comedian Michael Redmond is feeling philosophical: ldquoPeople say age is just a number. Seventy, for example, is just a number. But when you add years of age to it, its ****ing old.Cephalopod sillinessDAFT joke time. ldquoWhat language do squids speak  asks Julie Turner. ldquoInklish.Read more: Those were the days

title: letters-no-doubt-lockdown-saved-lives
story: As I wrote last week, I have been closely involved in the response to the pandemic, in my case within sport. Far from it being an exercise in stupidity those countries which responded immediately to the crisis through imposing lockdownhave come through the pandemic relatively unscathed, whilst others who delayed, including the UK, have suffered signicantly, and as we can see in the United States and Brazil, continue to suffer through their failure to introduce and sustain a coherent lockdown programme.I would be interested in knowing what Mr Adamss qualications are that allow him to make such an ill-considered sweeping statement supported by absolutely no empirical evidence whatsoever, or does he belong to the Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro school of medical wisdom That I am saddened by such remarks is because to my mind they exhibit a lack of respect for those who have lost their lives through a failure of governance and for the many more who would have died, and may still yetthe actions currently in place are not enforced rigorously a key part of which was lockdown. Such actions are not, nor have ever been, a joke.Bill Mitchell, Kyle of Lochalsh.IT was good that Robert Howiegot a lot off his chest in his letter to The Herald.Fortunately, the letter from Douglas Jardine which followed indicated why the people in Scotland should adhere to the actions recommended by FACTS and should wear a face mask at appropriate times .By doing this, we lessen our chances of becoming one of the millions affected by this global pandemic.Duncan Stirling, Cardross.ON July  Nicola Sturgeon insisted she wouldnt be rushed into dropping quarantine restrictions on airport arrivals, preferring to follow the science and her advisers. On that day, Spain declared  new cases. The very next day she dropped quarantine for most countries apart from Serbia and Spain. Spain announced  new cases that day.Yesterday, two weeks later, Spain reported a four-fold rise in new cases to , and Nicola Sturgeon dropped its quarantine restriction . Am I wrong in thinking her advisers are actually holidaymakers and opinion poll companies Allan Sutherland, Stonehaven.WITH the pandemic now under some kind of control in Scotland, would it not be best now for the First Minister to stand down from her almost daily announcements  She could let a health expert take over the daily update,it is deemed still necessary.It seems almost asshe has grown to love the spotlight and coverage and will have to be dragged screaming and kicking from the podium and cameras. An announcement in Holyrood, where she can be questioned properly, seems much more fitting for the present situation.Her daily ponticating long ago became a free, and unchallenged in any meaningful way, party political broadcast.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  So was the Russia report an attempt to taint the independence referendum
story: Itrsquos all there between the lines of yesterdayrsquos Russia Report. Though curiously, none of this Moscow gold ever found its way into my bank account. Perhaps I should head across and demand payment.At any rate, we were told by all news sources yesterday, that involvement of the Russians in the independence referendum was ldquoconfirmed by the report of the Commons Intelligence and Security Committee. The evidence lay in ldquoopen source commentary it said, which was ldquocredible.The UK Government scandalously ignored evidence of similar Russian involvement in the Brexit referendum, said MPs on the committee, because it didnrsquot want to know. Surprise, surprise.But how come the committee was so sure about Russkie meddling in the Indyref, about which the Government also apparently did not want to know  Why was the ldquoopen source commentary ldquoso compelling  After all, such commentary is just what people had been saying in published sources.There was no shortage of ldquoopen source commentary during Brexit from any number of commentators, such as the prolic Carole Cadwalladr in the Observer, who reported that senior Brexiters were in regular contact with Russian diplomats and business interests. Why did the committee disown all that The implication was that the true Indyref smoking gun was in the classied annex to yesterdayrsquos report. According to the former UK National Security Adviser, Sir Mark Lyell Grant, interviewed on BBC World At One, it was ldquowell known that the Russians were ldquoamplying social media messages during the  campaign. Well known by whom The published report refers only to claims about voting irregularities made after the  referendum and designed to discredit the result. It also referred obliquely to newspaper speculation about cybernat ldquoMcBots punting Russian propaganda.It rather looked asthe Labour and Conservative MPs on the committee were only able to agree on one thing: that the Russians were obviously all over the Scottish independence referendum and that the Government should have taken better note.According to the Labour MP, Kevan Jones, at yesterdayrsquos ISC press conference, the UK Government ignored the ldquoflashing lights from  and turned a blind eye to evidence that similar Russian ldquomeddling had occurred in the Brexit referendum in . Perhaps surprisingly, SNP MP Steward Hosie, who is also on the committee, took up the theme with alacrity. He chastised successive UK governments for not acting on known Russian involvement in the Scottish independence referendum: ldquoIt must have been clear that had they looked for similar evidence [in Brexit] it would have been extraordinarythey had not reached the same conclusions.Questioned later about this on BBC Radio Scotland, Mr Hosie said that he was only able to talk about what was in the unredacted report, not the secret annex. Thatrsquos all very well, but it leaves a nasty smell over the entire referendum campaign.I think we can all agree that the UK is ndash as the report put it ndash ldquoa top target for Russian security and intelligence services. But the activities of the IRA, the Internet Research Agency, which is assumed to be the perpetrator of these electoral dirty tricks, are almost incidental to the more serious activities of the Russian state. After all, it is widely assumed to have been conducting assassinations on UK soil using some of the most toxic agents known. This was against former KGB spies Alexander Litvinov and Sergei Skripal. These were terrorist actions and clearly a priority for the UKrsquos intelligence and security forces.But social media influencing is a rather dferent kettle of spooks. What I mainly recall from  were the widespread claims of vote-rigging and dirty tricks, not by the Kremlin but by MI. Many SNP supporters on Twitter believe the Alex Salmond sex case was orchestrated by the UK secret service.If, as the ISC committee recommended yesterday, MI spooks should now be actively investigating and judging social media posts during election campaigns, then yet more mistrust and paranoia will assuredly be the result. Why so sure  Because they are already doing this.It was revealed in  that the Institute for Statecraft, and its protege the Integrity Initiative, funded by the UK Foreign Office, was already battling Vladimir Putinrsquos social media meddling from the improbable location of a disused mill in Fe. The Integrity Initiative is all about countering ldquodisinformation and malign influence from Russia, which increasingly originates online.However, these hapless hacktivists strayed disastrously into domestic politics. The Integrity Initiative had to apologise to the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, for retweeting messages suggesting that he was one of Mr Putinrsquos ldquouseful idiots. Itrsquos not clear which of the institutersquos , tweets were alleging this, but we can guess.Ms Cadwalladr had claimed in  that senior members of the Labour Party including Jeremy Corbynrsquos communications director, Seumas Milne, were Russian patsies. ldquoMilnersquos support of Russia is like Faragersquos, she tweeted in December . ldquoTherersquos nothing hidden. Itrsquos completely overt.This is the problem with trying to fight a propaganda war on social media. Even more than conventional spying it is a hall of mirrors. Paranoia feeds paranoia. In calling for the intelligence services to start investigating election campaigns, the ISC committee is asking for something the spooks dearly want to avoid.Take Labourrsquos ldquoNHS for sale dossier, which became a major story in the  General Election campaign. This first appeared on the Reddit website. That websitersquos own security analysts claimed that, while the documents on Britainrsquos trade negotiations with the US were genuine, they were put into the public domain by Russian sources.Do we seriously want MI judging the veracity and origins of every election issue  Arguably, yesterdayrsquos ISC report was itself an exercise in political propaganda serving to taint the  referendum with Russian involvement. Yet there is precisely no evidence, compelling or otherwise, that this had any impact on the result. Keep spooks out of politics.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The HeraldRead more: The key points from the ISC report
