The priest at the funeral of popular young Portstewart man, Michael McQuillan, told mourners that his ability to ‘gather people around him’ brought out love in so many people. The -year-old passed away at his family home in the seaside town on Saturday night, causing widespread shock throughout the community. Fr Ciaran Dallat, who has known the McQuillan family for a number of years, told the congregation to treasure their memories of the popular young man. “You can rejoice in the  years that Michael has been with us,” he said. “Smicko’, for the lads over there, and wee Michael for most of his family, had a great way of gathering people around him. googletag.cmd.push “I know, in the midst of the fun, there was devilment, but wasn’t that what you liked about him  You didn’t know what was coming next, sometimes. “Each of you have your own stories and I’m sure most of the memories you had were good, but suddenly, in the space of a few days, they have become treasured.” Michael in action for his club, Eoghan Rua. Michael was a dual player for local GAA club Eoghan Rua, who have organised a memory box full of photographs and notes to be presented to his family. Fr Dallat said the support of the GAA community had ‘meant so much’ to Michael’s family. googletag.cmd.push “It’s obvious there just how much sport, and the lads and lassies involved, meant to him,” he said. “It meant so much to Margaret, Paul and Joseph this week, just to have them standing alongside them. “That’s what they were doing out there, just standing alongside people who they love and care for and saying, ‘we don’t know what to do here, but we’re going to stand alongside you anyway’. “That, in itself, is beautul, and it’s because Michael gathered people around him.” Michael’s ability to gather people around him formed a central part of Fr Dallat’s homily, and he spoke of how he was always able to make those around him feel ‘important’. “We have been blessed. It has been a joy to know him,” he told the congregation. “You only had to pass through the house over the last few days to see the love that this wee man has engendered in the time he has been with us. Eoghan Rua have arranged for a memory box to be presented to Michaels family. “Michael had some experience as a classroom assistant in Downpatrick, and the children loved him. He had an ability with children to gather them around and make them feel important. “The same is true here in Portstewart. It wasn’t only his peers he knew how to take care of and bring into the centre of the craic, but that was a gt as well.” Fr Dallat concluded by asking those who loved him to remember Michael for the joy he brought to others. “There are photographs and there are memories, but unfortunately, he won’t bound back into the house once more, looking for money to put petrol in the car for the next bit of the journey,” he said. “He was a man, who though small in stature, always dreamed big. He was someone who drew the love out of others. “Whatever name you have known him by, think for a moment about your favourite memory and thank God for the smile he has put on your face and for the love he has put in your heart.”   --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. The Minister of Education has decided that a -year-old Derry school will close next year. Last year, the Education Authorityproposed discontinuing Groarty Controlled Integrated Primary School because of the low number of pupils at the school. Groarty is the only integrated school on Derrys cityside. The proposal has now been agreed to by the Minister of Education Peter Weir. It had originally been proposed that the school would close at the end of August . However, the closure date has been extended to August . Mr Weir said: Having weighed up all the information, including the fact that  of the  pupils will be exiting P, with no new intake for - or September , it is clear that unfortunately the school is not sustainable, and that provision for any pupils in an integrated setting can be made where in the city. googletag.cmd.push The school has been a part of the local community for over  years. It attained integrated status in . A final decision regarding its closure was expected to be made by the department and Mr Weir at the beginning of this year. However, the decision was delayed because of the coronavirus pandemic. The number of pupils at the school has fluctuated over time but has not risen above  in the past ten years. Ahead of the   school year - before proposals were announced to close -  pupils enrolled. Following that decision, numerous parents took the decision to transfer their children to other schools which was reflected in enrolment figures of just  for the   school year. googletag.cmd.push The EA proposed closing Groarty Integrated Primary School, situated on the Coshquin Road, at the end of August . Parents were ‘devastated’ when first informed of the plans on April , . Schoolchildren from the school then hand delivered letters to then education chief, Derek Baker, when he visited Derry’s Guildhall imploring him to reconsider. The school has a capacity for  pupils and it was anticipated that by transforming from a controlled primary school to a controlled integrated primary school in  that numbers were going to swell. A consultation received  objections from amongst others the Board of Governors, staff, parents, a local resident and the Northern Ireland Council for Integrated Education. Points include the fact it is the only integrated primary school in the cityside and considerable distance to the other one, Oakgrove IPS, in the Waterside. The school caters for children with special needs and has a strong shared educational programme with Gaelscoil na Daroacuteige. The case was also made that housing developments are planned for the area which could improve numbers. However, the EA says that other schools close to Groarty, such as Irish Medium School Gaelscoil na Daroacuteige and Catholic Maintained Schools St Eithne’s and Holy Family have many unfilled places. A local councillor is concerned at the large number of young people gathering at a former school site in Derry. SDLP Councillor Shauna Cusack said young people have been holding parties and lighting fires at the former Foyle College site at Northland Road. Cllr Cusack said: This is a large site which unfortunately is very easily accessed. It is due to be the site for the new Ardnashee school with an estimated date of Spring  for the works to commence. We all know what happened with the old building when it had to be demolished last year following an arson attack and it seems the site has again become a magnet for anti social behaviour. googletag.cmd.push Cllr Cusack said that in recent weekslocal residents have reported large numbers of youths trying to access the site with drink. They have set up palettes for seating within the trees at the periphery of the site and can be heard partying into the early hours causing sleepless nights for the residents. The PSNI and the Council Community Safety Wardens have been in attendance and have witnessed evidence of drug taking also. This latest incident, which we all feared shows how these gatherings can escalate and get out of control engendering both themselves, others and surrounding property. I have been speaking with the authorities and directly with the Education Authority at the end of last week who had committed to removing materials and investigate private security to monitor the private site. googletag.cmd.push Meanwhile, I would ask parents and the public to play their part and either talk to your child about this area or report any trespass you see. While the obvious activities of underage drinking, drugs and now arson are very worrying we cannot forget the silent killer of Covid being transmitted when unmonitored crowds gather. The Bridewell building in Magherafelt is to get a temporary makeover. Three Mid Ulster District Council arts facilities will be lit up this weekend in recognition of the district’s frontline workers’ efforts during the Covid- pandemic. The Bridewell, Magherafelt, Ranfurly House, Dungannon and The Burnavon in Cookstown will light up red and white, the council colours, over the weekend. It comes after a motion, proposed by Deputy Chair, Meta Graham, at the council’s monthly meeting, received unanimous support. Cllr Graham wanted to publicly convey the council’s thanks to the workers who worked tirelessly outside the spotlight during the pandemic. “We all clapped deservedly week after week for our remarkable and brave NHS to show our support and to thank them for the sacrices they made during this dficult time,” she said. googletag.cmd.push “However, I think our thanks and appreciation need to be extended further to include all of those who are sometimes overlooked and quite often taken for granted. “We all need to pause and remember that while we may not have had everything we wanted during this crisis, thanks to the work of these dedicated workers, we certainly had everything we needed. “This gesture is a small token of our gratitude, appreciation and thanks to all those who have so selflessly kept Mid Ulster going over the last  months, often at considerable risk to themselves. We owe you all a great debt.” googletag.cmd.push Farmers, factory workers, delivery drivers, lorry drivers, postal workers, retail workers, the PSNI, the NIFRS, small local shops, council staff, volunteers and community groups were among those included by Cllr Graham.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Derry Citys glamour friendly game with Glasgow Celtic has been cancelled as the FAI pulled the plug on the clubs hopes of flying to Scotland to face Neil Lennons champions at the weekend. A spokesperson for the club confirmed the news last night after a day of uncertainly regarding the potential fixture. Originally scheduled to face League of Ireland champions Dundalk, Celtic were expecting to welcome the Lilywhites to Celtic Park, but quarantine restrictions ended their hopes of playing the game with anyone coming into the Republic from the UK having to self isolate for  days. With the League of Ireland set to start next Friday, that would have been impossible for the champions. googletag.cmd.push That opened the door for Derry City to step into the glamour friendly, with reports suggesting that former Celtic and City star Paddy McCourt was heavily involved in organising the game. The hope was that, as Derry City would only be travelling to another part of the UK from Northern Ireland, they are not bound by the same restrictions. That hope continued into yesterday, with the club hoping to finalise arrangements for the game, but they were dashed by the FAI last night. With City set to travel to Dublin to face St. Patricks Athletic, just eight days after the proposed game in Scotland, the same -day rule which scuppered Dundalks plans, also appear to have stopped Derry, despite technically being in the UK. googletag.cmd.push Instead of Celtic, City hope to finalise their pre-season plans with a game against Northwest neighbours Finn Harps behind closed doors at the Brandywell tomorrow night. Declan Devines men faced Cltonville in midweek and drew -, with the City boss running his eye over three new trialists. The Candystyripes face Sligo Rovers in the resumption of the league season next Friday. Celtic, meanwhile, who now wont have Irish opposition this weekend, finished off their mini tour of France with a - defeat at French giants Paris St-German, with superstars Kylian Mbappe and Neymar both on the scoresheet in the Parc des Princes encounter.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: ‘Leave us alone’ plea to vandals
story: DOWNPATRICK and County Down Railway officials have appealed to young people to ldquostop trying to destroy the place following a series of recent incidents.Vandals have targeted the award-winning heritage railway on three occasions, the incidents coming after officials warned that the attraction may not reopen this year as a result a cash crisis.Officials say the main gates at the railwayrsquos base at Market Street were forced open, while a fence at the Inch Abbey station was smashed.In addition, damage was caused to the lsquoLooprsquo . Fortunately, a fire, believed to have spread to undergrowth after an attempt was made to set a speed restriction sign alight, did not develop into a large blaze.The volunteers who run the railway mdash who have launched an urgent appeal to raise pound, mdash are particularly concerned about an attempt to force open the main gates they discovered empty beer cans. First aid boxes at the station were also raided for bandages.Damage at the Loop  was discovered during a recent shunt to test rolling stock and carry out essential track maintenance, with the exercise taking place while visitors were banned from the railway due to lockdown restrictions.Railway officials have reported the incidents to police and have appealed to anyone who can assist officers with their enquiries to come forward.The recent incidents come after the coronavirus lockdown had a massive hit on the railwayrsquos finances.In an online post, officials appealed to young people to ldquoleavethem alone and stop trying to destroy the place, also asking parents do they know where their children are and what they are doing.The hard-working volunteers say they have enough on their plate without having to ldquosort out other peoplersquos mess, expressing concern about people walking along the railway lines which they are not allowed to do.Officials say the ldquostupidity of others is the reason why they hope the local community will support their fundraising appeal to help pay for better security as a bid for financial help from the Northern Ireland Executive proved unsuccessful.A recent bid for support from the Department of Communitiesrsquo Covid- Charities Fund to cover costs racked up to maintain the business which has been mothballed due to lockdown restrictions was unsuccessful.Officials fear that the railway will also miss out on securing a slice of a poundm fund for business start-ups and tourist attraction investment which was announced recently.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner recently wrote an open letter highlighting the railwayrsquos plight and its reluctance to ask for help in the current financial climate.He said coronavirus restrictions have had a ldquodevastating impact on the railwayrsquos operations and its restoration work.Mr Gardiner said the railway was likely to remain closed for the remainder of the year due to the restrictions around Covid-.He said that with no income for the rest of the year, the railway faced ldquomajor challenges.Mr Gardiner said given that the railwayrsquos final attempts at securing Covid- support funding from Stormont failed, it had reluctantly turned to its members and supporters to ask for help.He added: ldquoWe need to raise at least pound, this year just to keep the railway in a good condition and make some progress with essential projects.To date, the railwayrsquos appeal has raised pound,, with anyone interested in making a donation asked to visit www.facebook donate   or text RAIL plus the amount to  or visit www.downrail appeal.prettyPhoto

title: Ambulance staff receive praise for work in lockdown
story: HEALTH campaigners have this week praised the excellent work of ambulance staff during the coronavirus pandemic.The tribute from the Down Community Health Committee comes after senior ambulance chiefs warned that response times in the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area and across the province could be delayed as coronavirus lockdown restrictions continue to ease.Ambulance Service officials have revealed that as as normality resumes, the organisation is facing ldquoincreased challenges in maintaining planned levels of cover and that the focus will be on the most serious cases.The anticipated delayed response times is being blamed on several factors, including increased activity levels without a rise in staff numbers.In addition, ambulance officials say almost one fth of its frontline staff are absent from work due to ordinary sickness or reasons related to Covid-.The Ambulance Service said longer term trends had seen demand for services rise in recent years without an accompanying increase in staff numbers, with a recent independent capacity review identying the need for  extra staff.Senior officials said the organisationrsquos challenges had been compounded by a ldquototally unacceptable increase in assaults on staff, many of whom were then forced to take time off work to recover.Ambulance Service chief executive Michael Bloomfield appealed for support from public representatives and the community to ensure that ambulances remain available to respond to le-threatening emergencies.ldquoI appreciate the genuine concern of community and political representatives when informed of shortages in a particular area, he said.ldquoHowever, I would like to reassure all stakeholders that we will continue to manage our available resources in a way which best serves the interests of patients and staff.Mr Bloomfield said members of the public also have their part to play.ldquoWe still receive too many calls for which options other than calling  are available, he said. ldquoWe would ask that people only consider calling  for real emergencies while, at the same time, advising people not to delay in the case of a real emergency.Health campaigners have praised both ambulance personnel for their work during dficult times and the excellent work done by other healthcare workers, support staff and members of the voluntary sector and private contractors.They say it is widely recognised that the Ambulance Trust has been a victim of ldquoserious under investment over a period of many years.ldquoIt is most important that the business case intended to secure essential investment referred to by Mr Bloomfield should be actioned swtly, stated campaigners.ldquoThere has been widespread dissatisfaction over a period of many years with ambulance response times generally and that to local communities in particular.The health committee has called for urgent steps to be taken by the organisationrsquos management to ensure that there is equality of access to services for all residents within the catchment area of the Ambulance Trust, whether they are urban dwellers or rural citizens.ldquoHealth inequalities are completely unacceptable and must be addressed in short, medium and long-term planning by the Trust and the Department of Health, the statement continues.ldquoTop priority must be given by the Ambulance Trust to areas like East Down that no longer have an easily accessible emergency department.ldquoA major element in the solution of the social distancing problem in other emergency departments is to move immediately to reopen the Downersquos AE. That is absolutely essential.Campaigners added: ldquoThe historic underinvestment in the Ambulance Service has been widely known for years. It is a pity that it was left seriously under resourced, facing into a pandemic..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass artist makes model of shipwrecked WW2 vessel
story: ARDGLASS artist William Mulhall recently completed work on a stunning model replica of a ship which ran aground on the Lecale coast more than  years ago.The Georgetown Victory ran aground at Killard Point, near Ballyhornan in , while on its way from Australia to Glasgow.All of the , servicemen aboard, who were due to be demobbed following the end of the Second World War, were rescued.Local farmers responded to the emergency and helped transport the troops to RAF coaches to take them to nearby Bishopscourt where they were served breakfast.A military convoy subsequently ferried the troops to an army barracks in Belfast where several hundred boarded a passenger steamer en route to Glasgow, their original destination.William has described the time he spent on making the new model as a ldquolabour of love and is keen to garner as much information as he can about the ship.While aware of what happened to the Georgetown Victory, he would like to broaden his knowledge of the disaster which occurred just a short distance from his home.William says he is keen for anyone who can help to either contact him by telephone or pop into his shop in his home village where they will also be able to see his model.ldquoI am pleased to have completed the model and it was special to work on a project that I remember my father talking to me about, he said.ldquoThe Georgetown Victory is an important part of the history of Lecale and I know there are many people out there who have more knowledge about then disaster than me. I would like them to get in touch.William said he has heard many reports about the disaster, including one relating to men from Portaferry who allegedly took a piano off the ship.The Georgetown Victory was a lsquoVictory Shiprsquo and was built in  at the Fortfield Shipyard at Bethlehem, Maryland, in the United States. She weighed in at , tons and was powered by two steam turbine enginesSays William: ldquoThe vessel was registered at Baltimore and when it left Fremantle for Glasgow with , Royal Navy men and marines due for demob. The crew mistook Strangford Lough for the River Clyde and the ship ran aground  yards off Killard Point, with her back breaking just forward of the bridge within a few hours of stranding.The Georgetown Victory had been converted from a cargo ship to a troopship able to transport up to , troops, with her cargo holds converted to bunk beds and hammocks stacked three high for hot bunking. In the cargo hold, mess halls and exercise areas were also added.Entering service near the end of the war, the Georgetown Victory and  other Victory troopships were given the task of transporting the troops home as part of Operation Magic Carpet. The vessel was operated by the American Export Lines.The ship departed Sydney with , troops steaming to Glasgow, stopping for water and fuel at Fremantle in Australia, Colombo in Sri Lanka and Aden in Yemen via the Suez Canal.On April , , just before midnight, the ship ran aground hard, at near top speed,  yards south of Killard Point.All of the servicemen aboard were rescued by leboats and breeches buoy to a tug started at about am.William said local people can remember some men wading ashore through heavy fuel oil from the stricken vessel to be cared for in nearby homes. The Cloughey and Newcastle leboats were also launched to help.Winter storms subsequently broke the wreck into two parts with all remaining portable gear not already taken by looters removed and the ship abandoned. The ship sections were salvaged in  and consigned to a breakerrsquos yard at Troon in Scotland.With his resplendent model now complete, William could be forgiven for sitting back on his laurels. But he has no intention of doing so.His next project will be making a model of the SS Bereby, a British merchant steamer built in  and owned by the Elder-Dempster Line.In , the vessel, which was carrying military stores and general cargo, was wrecked at Ringvad Point, near Gunnrsquos Island, while en route from Liverpool for Takoradi.Anyone who can assist William with information about the Georgetown Victory is asked to contact him on    or pop into his shop in Quay Street..prettyPhoto

title: Clarke converts penalty to help Down secure win
story: DOWN again flattered to deceive when getting the better of a plucky Longford in the second round of the All-Ireland Qualiers in Newry on Saturday night.Down will now travel to Offaly in the next round andthey win that game they will take on one of the four beaten provincial finalists for a place in the All-Ireland quarter-finals.The incessant, heavy rain made le dficult for both sides, but Down looked world beaters in the opening half before again fading the longer the game went on.It took a disputed th penalty from Martin Clarke to give Down a bit of breathing space as Longford hit back strongly in the second half and gave the home side numerous problems.Longfordrsquos Francis McGee, who scored - of his sidersquos tally, opened the scoring after just minutes as Down got used to playing Dan Gordon in an unaccustomed role at full back.Gordon, who replaced the injured Benny McArdle, was a revelation in a two-man full back line with Darren OrsquoHagan and manager James McCartan was more than happy with the Loughinisland manrsquos performance.ldquoPeople in the stand probably thought that our new defensive line-up was a bit radical, but Dan played full back against Louth and Laois in friendly games and we know just what he is capable of.Kalum King and Ambrose Rogers helped Down settle and unanswered points from Mark Poland, Benny Coulter and John Clarke pushed them into a three-point lead.A second McGee free reduced the deficit to two points, but Down simply moved up a gear and started to play the kind of football they are capable of.Martin Clarke converted a free before he split the posts from play and Danny Hughes tagged on another point as Down really looked the part.Longford responded with through another McGee free, but Down finished the half on a high and points from Poland and Martin Clarke gave them a - to - lead at the break.Noel Farrell grabbed the first score of the second half when he pointed a free, but this was cancelled out by a similar score from Hughes. Paul Barden kept Longford in the hunt when he scored a magnicent point from the sideline.Down continued to play well in patches and corner back Declan Rooney joined in one attack before lofting the ball over the par after some delightful passing.McGee cancelled this point out before Clarke converted from the penalty spot to give Down an eight point lead with  minutes remaining.Longford were helped a little when Downrsquos Kalum King was red carded after picking up two yellows and they took full advantage with McGee finding the back of the net with a clinical finish.Martin Clarke and McGee swapped frees before Hughes broke away in injury time to finally kill off a courageous Longford outfit.Down: B McVeigh, D Rooney , D Gordon, D Rafferty, D OrsquoHagan, J Colgan, C Garvey, A Rogers, K King, D Hughes , M Poland , B Coulter , C Maginn, J Clarke , M Clarke . Subs: K. McKernan for Garvey, C Laverty for J Clarke, P Fitzpatrick for Poland, A Carr for Maginn.Longford: D Sheridan, D Brady, B Gilleran, D Reilly, S Mulligan, E Williams, S Hannon, D Masterson, B McElvanney, P Dowd, P Barden , K Mulligan, F McGee , B Kavanagh, S McCormack. Subs: N. Farrellfor Hannon, P Kelly for Mulligan..prettyPhoto

title: Cricket is back at last
story: ITrsquoS a case of better late than never mdash after months of waiting, cricket is back this Saturday.Local clubs Downpatrick, Saintfield, Dundrum and Drumaness Superkings are all raring to go after the Covid- pandemic lockdown and also looking forward to renewing old rivalries.Downpatrick and Saintfield are both in Section  of the NCU League, while Dundrum and Drumaness are in the same group of a combined Sections  and .As a result of the shortened season all NCU competitions will be played under  over rules.The eight Premier league clubs will compete for the Robinson Services Cup, playing each other once with the top four going through to the semi-finals.The eight clubs will also play a knockout competition for the Lagan Valley Steels T Cup with the winner lining up in the All-Ireland T finals.The  Senior League  clubs will play each other once for the Robinson Services Trophy as well as a knockout competition for the Lagan Valley Steels T Trophy.Senior Leagues  and  are completely reorganised with the  clubs ided into three groups of four to compete for the Robinson Services Bowl. The teams will play each other home and away with the group winners and the best runner-up proceeding to the semi-finals.Given the changes the NCU has decided that there will be no promotion or relegation in .At Downpatrick club captain Ross Boultwood will be hoping the first eleven can carry on from where they left off last season.In one of the most dramatic finishes to a season in living memory, Downpatrick produced a late run of victories to narrowly avoid relegation on the last day.Downpatrickrsquos opening fixture on Saturday is away to Donaghcloney Mill and the locals will be hoping to get off to a good start.Also eagerly awaited is the trip to Saintfield on Saturday, August .Paul Tate is back as captain the second eleven. Only six games will be scheduled for the seconds but friendlies can also be arrangednecessary.Saintfield, who were promoted to Section  last year, are away to Ards on Saturday. Survival is the priority this season, but they have plenty of firepower in their ranks.Team captain Gareth Harrison will form a useful fast bowling partnership with TJ McCavera and they can also call on left arm spin twins Ethan Hanna and Patrick Telford, while  year-old Adam Reid a highly talented wicketkeeper and destructive batsman.At Dundrum, who are at home to Dunmurry on Saturday, new captain James Martin is confident that his players will be ready to compete with any team in the section.For the first time in a decade there is a very good first eleven squad of , including new signings Davy Glover from Victoria, Mark Topping from Dublin and Bruce Topping, who has come from Donaghcloney.There are also three new players from England. All-rounder Liam Kearsley and Charlie Rudge both played for Madeley in Shropshire and Jack Lambert, another good all-rounder, has been impressive in the nets.Adam Symington and Patrick Calvert have also looked impressive in practice, so deciding the batting order will be dficult.The selection committee will definitely have many tough decisions to make, but competition for places can only be good news for the villagers.The club also believes the  over format will suit their aggressive batsmen, so expect plenty of fireworks at the Meadow.There should also be fireworks at Drumaness Superkings, formed at the end of last year following the merger of Drumaness and Belfast Superkings.The club has taken over the maintenance of the ground from Newry, Mourne and Down Council and will be fielding three teams this season.The firsts open up with a trip to Belfast International Sports Club and have plenty of talent in their ranks.Team captain Mohammed Ismail will open the batting with James Cunningham, while the bowling duties will be shared by Muhammed Abid, Gary Walsh, Neil Walsh and Gary Moore.Club chairman Darren Oldroyd says he canrsquot wait for the action to begin.ldquoBecause of the merger we have secured the future of cricket in Drumaness, he said. ldquoWe have a nice ground, good support and plenty of history..prettyPhoto

title: Foodbank helps 1%2C100 people
story: THE Fountain Foodbank in Downpatrick helped over , people during the past  weeks of lockdown, it has been confirmed.The cross-community charity mdash based at Downpatrick Presbyterian Church ndash delivered around  food parcels as the global pandemic hit the district.Volunteers continued to deliver food parcels to those most in need with the charity extremely grateful to all those who helped in any way during what it described as ldquodficult circumstances.The scale of the pandemic forced the charity to implement a series of changes to help those in need, which included suspending its collection service.Parcels were subsequently delivered to peoplersquos homes by volunteers observing strict social distancing guidelines.Food parcels were left outside a clientrsquos door and volunteers did not enter anyonersquos homes.But this service ends next Wednesday, July .The charity has revealed that the easing of lockdown restrictions has paved the way for the foodbank toallow people to start calling at its base in Downpatrick for food parcels from next month.From Friday, August , parcels can be collected from the foodbank between am and noon with those in need of a food parcel required contact one of the foodbankrsquos referring partner organisations.Parcels need to be pre-ordered with volunteers from the referring organisations asking questions before providing a paper voucher or referring the iniduals to the foodbank via telephone or email.When the new measures governing the collection of parcels also come into force, visitors should not visit the foodbankthey are ill, while those who do call are required to wear a face mask and,possible, go alone.In addition, all callers must follow the one-way system and social distancing measures that will be in place.Hand sanitisers which have been provided must be used, with callers ready to hand over their voucher or referring information to the foodbank volunteers on duty.As the volunteers prepare for theof the collection service at their Downpatrick base, they are encouraging anyone in the community who needs help to get in touch for a referral over the coming weeks.The charity says it is particularly grateful to its donors and all those who continue to support its work, especially at what remains a dficult time for many.Food donations can continue to be made at dedicated collection points at the Asda and Supervalu supermarkets at the Ballydugan retail park and Ballymote shopping centre respectively.Everyone associated with the charity say they are grateful for all the support they continue to receive to help those in need during what are challenging times for everyone.The foodbank contact details are  , email fountainfoodbank@gmail or visit www.downpatrickpresbyterianchurch.org..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 15%2C 2000
story: BALLYNAHINCH ndash Senior Roads Service officials have this week been asked to play a key role to improve safety standards for people attending the weekly market in Ballynahinch.Councillor Anne McAleenan has expressed her concern for the safety of people who are regular visitors to a number of stalls which skirt the outskirts of the Department of Regional Developmentrsquos Windmill Street car park in the town.The weekly market now operates at the car park and the town square and Mrs McAleenan said many elderly people who make their way to this area for their weekly shop have to watch out for cars and Post Office vans making their way to a local depot.The local councillor said Road Service officials are responsible for road safety matters and must take whatever action is necessary at the Windmill Street area to protect local residents, in particular the elderly.ldquoRoads Service officials must put more effort into this area. Many old people attend the weekly market and they have a right to be able to do their shopping in safety, she said.Mrs McAleenan said part of the Town Square, the traditional home of the weekly market, was given up to allow work to begin on the townrsquos new one-way traffic system.ldquoAs a result, it now operates at two sites and the Department must realise it has a duty of care to protect shoppers at the Windmill Street area, she added.Mrs McAleenan also urged Roads Service officials to join forces with Down Council officers and members of the Ballynahinch Regeneration Committee to come up with a suitable venue for the traditional weekly market.KILLYLEAGH ndash Demolition work to pave the way for one of the biggest housing developments ever proposed for Killyleagh is currently underway.Developers Hagan Homes have begun demolishing buildings at the former Killyleagh Yarns factory on the Downpatrick Road where it plans to develop  new homes at the sprawling five acre site.It is over a year since the housing firm bought the site for pound.m at a public auction and a mix of new homes is to be constructed over the coming months.They include semi-detached houses, cottages and apartments and the developers are confident the new homes will help regenerate that area of the town.They are promising to provide homes and apartments which boast high quality design, particularly as part of the development site falls within Killyleaghrsquos designated conservation area.But not all the former mill buildings will be bulldozed to make way for the new homes. A number will be retained and developed into apartments to ensure the character of the conservation area is retained.Several old buildings, including the old engine house, will be converted into flats and surrounded by semi-detached homes and cottages.NEWCASTLE ndash Crime is on the increase in the Newcastle area, according to recently published police figures.Latest statistics reveal a particularly sharp increase in incidences of burglary, criminal damage theft and, more specically, theft from vehicles.A total of  criminal damage offences were recorded in   compared to  the year before, while the number of recorded thefts has increased by .Also growing in number are reported cases of frauds, forgery and drug offences committed in the seaside town and outlying areas.Over the past three years, there has been a marked sea-change in the quantities and types of drugs seized by police in the Newcastle area.Whereas cocaine and cannabis accounted for the majority of narcotics hauls in the   period, the past year has seen a greater prevalence of amphetamines seizures.DUNDRUM ndash The sun shone down brightly for the official opening of Down Districtrsquos latest tourist amenity.An pound, holiday development, aimed at addressing the dirty of tourist accommodation in Dundrum, has been completed after seven years of preparation.The tourist centre, funded by the International Fund for Ireland, Down Council and the Department for Social Development, and initiated by the villagersquos regeneration committee, has been hailed by tourist chiefs throughout the district as an ldquoundisputed boost to the local economy.It is hoped the development, which includes a restaurant, tourist centre sand eight self-catering holiday homes, will encourage tourists to spend their holidays at the village.The Tonn Ruray restaurant, a circular building with stunning views over the bay, is now open for parties, seminars and small weddings, while reservations for the holiday homes have already taken off.BALLEE ndash Members of Ballee Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church took to the roads recently to visit a number of other Non-Subscribing churches.But Saturdayrsquos journey was one with a dference, and took place with members in the back of a tractor.The -mile event was organised to raise funds for the restoration of the church hall.Clough, Killinchy and Templepatrick were just some of the towns and villages passed through during the -hour hike, during which nine members took turns at the wheel of the tractor.Church members extend their thanks to Allan Chambers for supplying the tractor and to others who helped throughout the day.STRANGFORD ndash Roads Service officials have this week been praised for carrying out work on a scheme in the Strangford area.Local councillor Peter Craig said he and local residents were delighted work to repair a bank between The Links and Fairways has been completed.Mr Craig said a number of flagstones have been laid in the area and hopes other safety improvements are in the pipeline.DOWNPATRICK ndash A former teacher at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School made a welcometo the Downpatrick school recently.Brother Anthony Furness, FSC, who taught science at St Patrickrsquos in the s, was back in County Down after a long absence.He now lives and teaches in South Africa, but ed to Downpatrick to meet some old friends, in particular Mr Brian Magorrian, the schoolrsquos vice-principal, who retired last week.Mr Magorrian, who was one of his first A-Level students at St Patrickrsquos in the Fties and was taught by Bro Anthony, who also taught at St Patrickrsquos Boysrsquo Primary School before moving to the lsquoRed Highrsquo.A graduate in chemistry, he taught science and went on to introduce A-Level physics at the high school.During his visit Bro Anthony saw some of the schoolrsquos new facilities and enjoyed reminiscing about his years at the school. His other former pupils included Dr Jim Hamill, Michael OrsquoCleary-Clarke, Jim Curran, the former head of science at East Down Institute of Further Education, and Tony Rice, who went on to study engineering.CROSSGAR ndash A local Womenrsquos Institute branch is casting off the traditional image of jam making and flower arranging by launching its very own site on the Internet.Announcing the news of the Crossgar Womenrsquos Institute site the grouprsquos secretary, Sheila McMurray, explained how the idea of a website came about and how the  members of the Institute aimed to dispel the stereotypical image of the organisation.ldquoIt started with the idea that we should do something to mark the Millennium. After much debate the committee decided that since this is very much the information technology age we should develop our own website, she said..prettyPhoto

title: German delight as Annahilt teenager Harper secures win
story: ANNAHILT teenage racing driver Daniel Harper secured a memorable first victory in the Nuumlrburgring Endurance Series in Germany at the weekend.The revised calendar for the  season saw the second and third rounds of the series take place on the same weekend, meaning  year-old Harper and his BMW Junior Team stablemates, Neil Verhagen and Max Hesse, contested a four hour race on each day.If that wasnrsquot already a busy enough schedule, Harper also found himself in the unique position of competing in two cars in the same races ndash identical BMW Mi racing machines for the FK Performance and Walkenhorst Motorsport teams.This was because he and his team-mates needed to complete a set number of laps of the Nordschlee circuit to upgrade their circuit permits. If successful, they would then be able to step up to a BMW M GT for the next round of the series.Prior to each dayrsquos race, there was a -minute qualying session to tackle.On Saturday, Harper starred as he qualied the FK Performance car second quickest in the competitive Mi Racing class, while Verhagen put the Walkenhorst car fth.The  year old started the race behind the wheel of the FK Performance car and moved up to second place on lap two. Edging clear of the pack behind, Harper maximised the rest of his stint to get some crucial experience of traffic management in multi-class racing.After handing the car over to Hesse, Harper had a short break before taking the final stint in the Walkenhorst machine.He ran in the podium places until the closing stages, when a late pitstop meant he eventually led his team-mate home to fth and sixth in class.On Sunday, Harperrsquos attention was focused solely on the FK Performance prepared BMW and a strong start in qualying saw him place them third on the class grid. He went on to start the race behind the wheel, tackling a double stint of over two hours.Staying out of trouble during the busy opening laps, the BRDC SuperStars member fought to second place and held it throughout the early stages. Consistent lap times kept him in touch with the leader and he moved to the front of the class during the first pitstop cycle.A brilliant performance from there saw him post a new circuit lap record for the Mi as he built a lead of  seconds before handing the car over to Verhagen.The American took full advantage of the prime position and led to the finish to secure them the class win.Harper said afterwards: ldquoIrsquom absolutely over the moon to score a victory in class in just our third race together as the BMW Junior Team.ldquoI think everyone is in some shock as we didnrsquot expect to challenge the Mi class experts, let alone beat them in our second true race.ldquoIrsquom pleased with my pace across the event, particularly in race two. I loved my first experience of a double stint and to set a new lap record for the car so late into my run was mega. Neil and Max both drove superbly too and as a team it was a great weekend..prettyPhoto

title: Hall pens new deal
story: BALLYNAHINCH defender Greg Hall has signed a new one year contract at Portadown.Hall arrived at Shamrock Park from Ards in January  and slotted into the right back berth, where he has remained ever since.A firm favourite with the Porrtadown fans, he picked up a injury against Ballyclare Comrades in November which has resulted in him missing the remainder of the season.However, he should be fit and raring to go for the new season as the Portsto the Danske Bank Premiership.In   he picked up the Players Player of the Year award and the Richhill Reds Player of the Year award.Ports boss Matthew Tipton said he was thrilled with Hall signing a new deal, describing him as a ldquomodel professional who has always given his all for the club.He added: ldquoEven though he was injured for a chunk of last season I could see how hard he was working to get back fit for the run-in and Irsquom delighted to have him on board for next season.Hall has also had spells with Loughgall, Lisburn Distillery and Ballynahinch United..prettyPhoto

title: James wins international short story competition
story: A SECOND local young writer has been honoured for his environmentally-themed writing.James Lavery from Ballykinlar has won the international childrenrsquos magazine AQUILArsquos -word short story competition.The  year-oldrsquos story has been featured in a magazine with , subscribers and made the front cover of the magazinersquos recent edition.Jamesrsquo success of the follows fast on of that of  year-old Dara McAnulty from Castlewellan whose debut book, The Diary of A Young Naturalist, has been critically acclaimed.Jamesrsquo story mdash Battle for the Amazon mdash was inspired by Colin Dannrsquos The Animals of Farthing Wood, which tells of a group of woodland animals whose home is set to be paved over by developers.The eldest son of Mark and Alison Lavery, James decided to site his story of survival in the Amazon forest as its ecosystem and animals are under threat due to over mining and logging and the effects of mankind.He said of his story which takes a wry insight into the animal world and its hierarchy: ldquoThe narrator is an eagle called H, I call him the Happy eagle in my story. I came up with the idea for his story by myself, my parents only knew about it when I told them I had won.James and his brothers Connand eight year-old Dara have been home-schooled for two years in a lsquoscreen freersquo learning environment.His mum Alison, who is a teacher, follows a child-centred curriculum, with methods and materials inspired by Maria Montessori.AQUILA is regarded as ldquothe ultimate intelligent read for inquisitive kids and is posted to more than  countries worldwide including UK, Ireland, America, Australia and New Zealand..prettyPhoto

title: Jules on top of the world at Matterhorn
story: IT was the hug at the top of the Matterhorn that told Chris Molyneaux his son was proud that he had just climbed one of the highest peaks in Europe mdash at the age of .The former Co Down man was not surprised that his youngest child, Jules, completed the arduous climb at such a young age.The naturally gted young sportsman has been loving the thrill and achievement of climbing since he was a toddler.At just under , metres high, the Matterhorn in the Swiss Alps is a challenging climb due to its sheer pyramid shape and requires rock climbing expertise and strength to scale it.The challenge is reflected in that  people have died on the mountain, including a  year-old man let Wednesday when Chris and Jules successfully completed their climb.Climbing in two pairs with an experienced mountain guide each, father and son left camp just before am and reached the summit just over four hours later.ldquoThe Matterhorn is one of the deadliest peaks in the world and on the day of our climb, there was more snow than our guide has seen in  years and there were lots of falling rocks, said Chris. ldquoBut there was no issues for Jules during the climb,. If there had have been, the guide would have stopped and taken him down.Jules was later told by the Matterhorn Museum that itrsquos believed he was the youngest person ever to have mastered the peak.Chris, now living with his family in the Scottish Highlands where he and his we Mignonne run a gin distillery, Daffyrsquos, said: ldquoJules has always loved climbing since he was able to walk. Whether it was trees or rocks, he progressed doing indoor climbing walls and roped up climbing outdoors.A former professional snowboarder, Chris grew up on Sketrick Island, near Killinchy, with his parents, Zora and Paul.He developed a love of mountains and climbing as a child in the Mournes and through his schoolrsquos mountaineering club, so it was inevitable he would pass on his passion for the outdoors to Jules and his elder brother,  year-old Louis.ldquoWersquove always climbed as a family but several years ago Jules was asked to do a school project on any subject and he chose to do one on climbing the Matterhorn, explained Chris.ldquoOne day he asked mehe could climb the Matterhorn some time and I said of course, rather thinking it was a joke.ldquoBut Jules really put in the training himself and kept pushing me to take on a hike or a climb. He was always very capable as we have always climbed as a family.Chris said that Jules continued to put the work into building up his skills and stamina for the climb mdash even the Covid- could not defeat the  year-oldrsquos determination to climb the mountain.ldquoWe had lined up an American friend of ours to guide us, but he couldnrsquot travel due to the pandemic so we thought we would go with the local mountain guides.ldquoHowever, they told Jules that he couldnrsquot do it until he was  and after he proved himself. We did a lot of high altitude extreme rock climbs. They watched Jules, saw that he was very capable and decided to give him a shot.While Chris was prepared to try and make his sonrsquos ambition to come true, even he was surprised when they safely made the summit and ed back down without incident.ldquoI donrsquot think I fully expected we would make it to the top, admitted Chris. ldquoJules gave me a hug at the very top and said he couldnrsquot believe he had done it. He thought it was incredible but it did take a while for it to sink in afterwards.While Jules may be eligible for an entry into the Guinness Book of Records, his dad said that accolade is not what Jules was about.ldquoHersquos not a glory hunter in any sense, hersquos just appreciative and proud to have done it. Jules wasnrsquot doing it for a record, he just wanted to climb the Matterhorn, for the achievement of it.And Chrisrsquos prediction of what his son might achieve in the future  ldquoIrsquom not sureJules will go for a career as a climber, hersquos more about adventure and would love to be a great adventurer whether itrsquos skateboarding, skiing, ing, sailing. Jules just loves adventure. Hersquos a very good fencer, swimmer, footballer and is a bit of an all-rounder really..prettyPhoto

title: Lighthouse campaigners continue bid to save beam
story: CAMPAIGNERS opposed to changes at the historic St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse near Killough have reaffirmed their ldquohands off warning to the Commissioner of Irish Lights.Their renewed determination to retain the lighthousersquos iconic sweeping beam and rotating mechanism mdash which turns a huge Fresnel lens mdash comes after it emerged that the Dublin-based organisation has started the tendering process to remove it.Despite widespread opposition locally, the Commissioners of Irish Lightsis seeking tenders from specialist companies to remove liquid mercury from St Johnrsquos Point and six other lighthouses across Ireland over the next six years, beginning with two on Rathlin Island.CIL is planning to replace the current rotating mechanism at the Killough lighthouse and replace the light with a modern, low-powered LED alternative, while retaining the existing lens.But campaigners are calling for the proposal to be scrapped and are concerned that tender documents have been issued, despite local politicians and residents vehemently opposing any changes at St Johnrsquos Point.CIL insists it is planning minimal changes and aims to remove mercury from the lighthousersquos current rotating lens mechanism and replace it with a German-made alternative.In addition, the organisation insists that the engineering works planned for the Killough lighthouse will deliver a ldquobetter quality, environmentally superior solution which meets modern health and safety requirements.CIL argues it is simply removing mercury out of the rotating lens system and putting in an innovative mechanical bearing solution. However, the claims have been firmly rejected by local people keen to see the controversial plan aborted.According to the tender documents, CIL wants to replace the existing beam with a more environmentally friendly LED light, maintaining that it can do this while retaining the traditional lens.And CIL says while mercury has been used to rotate large revolving Fresnel lenses since the s, with the system providing a near frictionless environment, it describes mercury as a ldquotoxic substance.While pointing to many years of reliable service, the organisation says there is increasing European and international legislation restricting the use, storage and transport of mercury.CIL maintains while it has no immediate statutory requirement to remove mercury from lighthouses, it has been its policy that where re-engineering capital projects are being carried out at lighthouses, ldquothe opportunity is taken to remove mercury.The organisation says with no other liquid medium available to replace mercury, alternative solutions are designed on a station by station basis to provide visual aid to navigation.CIL claims that trials on an alternative bearing at Tory Island lighthouse which started in  ensures the reliability of the bearing solution proposed for St Johnrsquos Point where it plans to retain the existing Fresnel lens which it recognises as important to the heritage of the station and local area.ldquoAs part of the engineering upgrade works, the mercury will be removed from existing optic installations and will be replaced by a mechanical bearing to provide an alternative rotation mechanism, states the tender documentation. ldquoOnly the liquid mercury will be removed and the remaining apparatus will be retained unchanged.ldquoIt is the intention to award the contracts for mercury removal at Rathlin East and Rathlin West lighthouses initially and appoint the successful tenderer for future removals.A spokeswoman for the Lecale Lightkeepers campaign group battling to retain the lighthouse in its current guise, suggested that local politicians will be ldquoperplexed that CIL has effectively ignored their wishes on the issue and the protection of the iconic sweeping beam.She said Newry, Mourne and Down Council unanimously decided to oppose any changes and was firmly standing alongside the local community on the issue.ldquoThe people and politicians are as one on this issue, the spokeswoman declared. ldquoSt Johnrsquos Point lighthouse is part of the arearsquos unique maritime history and heritage and must not be changed in any way.ldquoWhy is CIL issuing tender documentation when it has not told local politicians and indeed the people of Killough why it is proceeding without further discussion with them  Why is CIL ignoring the wishes of elected representatives She continued: ldquoWe have consistently asked for this beautul lighthouse to be simply left as it is. It is working perfectly andit isnrsquot broke, donrsquot fix it. We have consistently argued that the mercury issue is a red herring and nothing we have seen or heard has made us deviate from this position.ldquoSt Johnrsquos is one of the best ventilated lighthouses of its kind and we are opposed to any orce from the current Fresnel lens and its Burdel rotating mechanism.Campaigners say they hope that politicians will seek an urgent, virtual meeting with CIL to ask why their wishes have been ignored and why they were not formally told that the tendering process had begun.The campaign spokeswoman added: ldquoThe St Johnrsquos Point lighthouse boasts what is widely regarded as a rare bit of engineering excellence which we want retained and maintained. The iconic sweeping beam and rotation system must not be lost at the stroke of a pen and consigned to the pages of history. We will not let this happen..prettyPhoto

title: Lyons roars to victory
story: CROSSGAR Golf Club hosted its first open competition of the year at the weekend.A large crowd turned out in good conditions for the event, which was sponsored by the Central Bar.Early riser Neil Hanvey set the clubhouse target with  points.Lee Hanna, also an early starter, just fell short with  points but this was enough to secure him third place, beating veteran Davy Hanna on the countback.The winner was Coalisland man John Lyons who continued his early season form, blitzing the field with a magnicent  points.The gross prize, predictably, went to lsquoMr Consistentrsquo Davy Watson and his son, Curtis, claimed the juvenile prize with  points.Damian Bell won the battle of the guests with  points.The ladiesrsquo competition proved a much closer affair with only one point separating the first three.Anne McCart was a little unlucky to miss out on a prize but got some consolation with the only lady to have a two.Elizabeth Patterson got her season off to a good start with the runners-up spot but the winner was a delighted Isobel Hyde who was celebrating her first big win since recently rejoining.The club is grateful to Brian and Kerri-Ann OrsquoHare for their continued support, especially in these trying and uncertain times..prettyPhoto

title: MoT centres open
story: DRIVERS across the district are heading back to Downpatrickrsquos MoT centre this month.The Driver and Vehicle Agencyhas begun a phasedof MoT tests, with driving tests also set to resume.MoT tests for what are being described as ldquopriority vehicle groups began on Monday and testing for other vehicles is due to recommence in August.There are also plans to reinstate some driver testing services in July, but these will only be allowed to proceedthey can be done safely and social distancing requirements can be met.Stormont infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon said ldquoofficials have been working hard to find solutions to help customers.Ms Mallon said the DVA has carried out ldquoa full review of risk assessments and developed new MoT processes that comply with all the published government public health advice and guidance.The minister continued: ldquoA number of measures have been put in place including a range of exemptions and extensions so that, as far as possible, vehicles can be kept on the road safely and most people can keep driving.ldquoCovid- has caused unprecedented dficulties for all of us and I thank our customers for their patience at this very challenging time.Ms Mallon also confirmed that new lts have been installed at  of the provincersquos test centres. MoT tests were suspended in January after faults were detected in some of the lts.The minister also said that she ldquorecognises frustrations that many people have been unable to take driving tests and the inconvenience this has caused.She confirmed that consultation is ongoing with trade unions with a view for the phasedof driving tests..prettyPhoto

title: New bypass can help regenerate Ballynahinch
story: THE new Ballynahinch bypass can help kick-start the economic regeneration of the town and provide the wider South Down tourism economy with a signicant boost.Thatrsquos the assertion of one man who for decades was at the heart of the long campaign to secure the new multi-million pound scheme.Francis Casement was a key member of Ballynahinchrsquos Regeneration Committee for many years and alongside the late Vincent Fullam, never gave up the battle to secure a bypass first mooted in the late s.Sadly, Mr Fullam passed away earlier this year and never got to hear the news that work on the eagerly-anticipated scheme could potentially start before next March.Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon has included the near two-mile bypass in a list of strategic projects that will be progressed during the current financial year, with the Ballynahinch project effectively ready to proceed.Never before has the Ballynahinch scheme been accorded such a high priority by the Department of Infrastructure, with all attention now focusing on confirmation of a start date.Major progress has been made over recent years to advance the scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads and alleviate chronic town centre congestion and along the main approach roads to the town.The bypass mdash now at the shovel ready stage ndash is the single biggest road scheme ever proposed for the district, with suggestions that it could take at least  months to construct.In , Mr Casement was instrumental in securing traffic counting machines in a bid to determine the number of vehicles passing through the town centre.They revealed that almost two decades ago, tens of thousands of vehicles passed through the town centre daily with particular hotspots including Main Street, Church Road, High Street, Crossgar Road, Loughside Drive and Harmony Hill Road.And while the figures were subsequently questioned by roads officials, Mr Casement and Mr Fullam, who worked alongside former town centre manager, Eric Tomasinni, were confident that their traffic count figures were spot on.Reflecting on how many years it has taken for a formal government commitment to construct the much-needed bypass, Mr Casement says he remembers plans for a new link from the Belfast Road across to Glasnevin Quarry and on to Drumaness in .ldquoThere were a number of homes along the suggested route and the road was never built. Now things have changed signicantly and the hard work of many people, including local MPs, MLAs, councillors and roads officials have paid off, he said.ldquoThere have been many  dawns over the years but we are now at the stage that work could start within a year which is good news. It is a great pity that Vincent is not here to see this happening.For a number of years, Mr Casement and Mr Fullam were the sole flag-bearers for the bypass, ensuring that the project was firmly in the public eye.While the scheme was making slow progress, the regeneration officials refused to concede defeat and organised a number of meetings, inviting business representatives from across South Down. They recognised that the construction of the bypass was as crucially important for hauliers north of Ballynahinch as it was for those as far south as Kilkeel as their lorries were often caught up in traffic hold-ups on the main approaches to and from Ballynahinch.ldquoThe support for the bypass from all quarters was overwhelming, continued Mr Casement.ldquoI have lost count of the number of locally elected and direct rule ministers who came to Ballynahinch to learn more about the bypass. Confirmation that it is now tantalisingly close proves that you must never give up, just keep chipping away and stating your case.The former regeneration official also recalled a suggestion to construct the bypass and recoup the money spent on building it by charging drivers to use it.He said while there were some opposed to the idea, a number of leading hauliers were in favour as it would save them not only time, but fuel costs as lorries would not be sitting in traffic burning diesel.ldquoIt has been a long haul to get to this point and so many people have worked hard on this project. Successive isional roads managers were in favour of the bypass but there was never the money to work on its finer detail and move it to the shovel-ready stage, explained Mr Casement. ldquoThat position subsequently changed and the scheme has now reached a pivotal point.While the primary focus of the bypass is on easing traffic congestion, Mr Casement said the scheme brings with it a number of benefits.ldquoReducing tailbacks will help the environment and perhaps one of the most important aspects of the bypass is that will deter drivers from using a number of heavily populated housing areas as unofficial bypasses, including the Loughside, Carlisle Park and Langley Road areas, he continued.ldquoThe bypass can hopefully kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre, encouraging new retailers and more shoppers. I believe that the current congestion can deter people who decide to shop where.Mr Casement said the proposed bypass can also benefit the wider South Down area as visitors from Belfast will be able to avoid Ballynahinch town centre.ldquoBallynahinch is regarded as the gateway to the Mournes and that position will be firmly cemented when the new link road opens. The scheme has never been this close in my letime and I hope that it wonrsquot be long before contractors are on the ground.ldquoBallynahinch residents and the townrsquos business community deserve this scheme. It is decades overdue and when it was confirmed recently that the project is well placed on the list of priority government schemes I was delighted.ldquoBut I was conscious that my good friend Vincent was not here to enjoy a moment that he had dedicated a large part of his le to achieving.With all eyes now on the Department for Infrastructure to confirm a bypass start date, Mr Casement hopes that it will be soon.ldquoIt has taken signicantly longer to reach this point than any of us ever imagined, but we have made it, added Mr Casement. ldquoThe icing on the cake will be confirmation of a start date and people are eagerly awaiting this announcement..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle ADHD Hub reopens to visitors
story: THE ADHD Hub in Newcastle reopened last Friday.Situated in Savoy Lane, the Hub closed in March at the start of the lockdown.It is an autistic contact centre and coffee shop, managed by Janet Cunningham who is assisted by a host of volunteers.The lockdown affected many ADHD and autistic adults and young people who use the Hub and its facilities on a regular basis.The Hub is open Thursday through to Sunday evening. Facilities include an art club, a therapy room and a sensory room.Newcastle Lions Club helped with the reopening to ensure the health and safety of volunteers and visitors was maintained.To help promote the Hub the Lions also agreed to design and supply an advertising standard for the front of the premises.A spokesperson for the Lions said: ldquoThis community-driven, volunteer-led service has helped provide respite for those with ADHD and autism and their families..prettyPhoto

title: Ruairi signs deal with The Ports
story: CASTLEWELLAN striker Ruairi Croskery has signed for newly promoted Dankse Bank Premiership side Portadown.The  year-old has signed a two year contract at Shamrock Park ahead of the - season.Croskery spent four years at Manchester United and featured in the same Un- squad as current first team stars Marcus Rashford and Scott McTominay.After his spell at Old Trafford he ed back to Northern Ireland to sign for Linfield. However, he made just one senior appearance for the Blues, scoring a second half header in a - win over Glenavon at Mourneview Park.From Windsor Park he moved to Warrenpoint Town where he would play under his new manager at Portadown, Matthew Tipton.He helped the club win the Championship in the   season before moving to America.Croskery has spent the last three years at Limestone University in South Carolina where he played for Limestone College in the NCAA D Soccer Championship.While at Limestone he was selected for the Conference Carolinas All-Tournament team in  and in was named as the Conference Carolinas Tournament Most Outstanding player.Ports manager Tipton said: ldquoIrsquom delighted to get Ruairi signed. Hersquos someone I worked with at Warrenpoint before he went to America on a football scholarship three years ago.ldquoWersquove stayed in touch over that time and Irsquom surprised he didnrsquot block my number with me constantly asking when he was coming home to sign for us.ldquoRuairi has the ability to play in any of the forward positions and offers us something completely dferent to what we have now in terms of style of play.He added: ldquoI donrsquot want to put too much pressure on him, but I think hersquos a player our fans will get excited about and one our players will enjoy playing with.On signing for Portadown, Croskery said: ldquoI always kept in contact with Matthew Tipton over the three years I was in America and I told him I would come home to him.ldquoOnce he got the Portadown job I followed him on social media and I feel like Irsquove been here for two years already. Irsquove been speaking to him following the whole thing.Speaking about how he will fit into the system at Portadown, he said: ldquoIrsquoll play anywhere, I started as a striker at a young age played there for five years.ldquoI then played as a number  at Warrenpoint and when I went to America played on the left and right wing. Anywhere in the attack Irsquom fine with that, so Irsquom looking forward to it.Outllining his ambitions for the new season, he added: ldquoIrsquom confident we can do well. Wersquove got a young squad here.ldquoEverybodyrsquos hungry and Irsquom hungry coming in and I think wersquoll do well. Irsquove no doubt that wersquoll stay up and push on from there..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde couple transform basement into movie room
story: A FAMILY of movie buffs from Seaforde are enjoying their own silver screen experience during lockdown after designing a cinema in their basement.For many, the loss of enjoying the latest blockbuster at the cinema has been a big social adjustment.Interior designer Jacqueline Hamilton , and her quantity surveyor husband Tonywere diehards for their regular cinema haunt, often accompanied by their son, Rudi , daughter Daisyand niece Dulcie Maguire , who all regularly went to the Downpatrick Omniplex before lockdown.Such was their love for the movies that a plan was devised to make their own cinema at their home last year.And the finishing touches have finally be put on the basement move theatre during lockdown.Jacqueline, who had previously worked in post-production in the film industry and now runs Seaforde Interiors, designed the cinema.She said her inspiration came from Londonrsquos Soho and the set of BBCrsquos Strictly Come Dancing.ldquoI used to work in post-production in Soho where we did commercials, features and TV shows. We had the most beautul Art Deco Vaudeville theatre for celebrities, actors and directors to view their work. So I always loved it and knew I wanted to create something like that when it came todesigning the cinema, explained Jacqueline.Jacqueline reeled in her professional interior design skills, repurposing household items and getting inspiration from the dance showrsquos judgesrsquo table for her home cinema.She said: ldquoTony and I moved back home from London and built our home where we had a basement constructed. But it became a storage area and the kids were sitting more or less in the middle of it.ldquoWe drove up to Belfast and got wadding to line the walls. When we ran out of wadding, we just used old duvets. We covered the wadding with red velvet. That made the room soundproof.ldquoWe are cocooned watching a movie and a massive thunder storm would pass without us even hearing it. Tony did the building work by and the kids helped. We called them the film crew.ldquoI also got gold paint and mixed that with glitter to give the old-style feel of the movie room. We made a bar thatrsquos inspired by the judgesrsquo  table on Strictly Come Dancing. I was watching the show one night and thought Irsquod like to make something like that.The Art Deco-style columns were Billy bookcases from Ikea that we painted. I had a mirror bought for me that needed a place to hang it and we put that in the bar where it really suits. A relative bought us a popcorn machine for added authenticity.She said that from creating the mood board for the project to when it was completed took four weeks, but it really was not used until lockdown.ldquoBefore the Covid- restrictions, the cinema was something we had started and used a bit. When lockdown came and the cinemas closed, the kids were never out of our cinema, she said.ldquoThe kids can go in there and watch their Netflix and Disney Plus mdash we have Sky, Netflix and every other movie and plus channel going now during lockdown so we can get the newly released movies as they are streamed.ldquoNow therersquos so much satisfaction with it. Itrsquos something special we designed and built as a family and now use as a family. Itrsquos a special place because we all have invested our time, love and effort into it.However, there are no plans to rule out trips to the cinema after they are allowed to reopen.Jacqueline added: ldquoWe will continue to support our local cinema. Our home cinema is great but therersquos nothing like the real thingThe movie theatre, whether it be modern or old-style, is a magical place and I hope we all continue going to the movies and supporting our cinemas for many years to come..prettyPhoto

title: Spa Wells group delivers 60 good parcels to residents
story: MEMBERS and volunteers of Spa Wells Cultural Association distributed  food parcels in the area recently.The parcels were delivered to elderly residents and those shielding due to coronavirus.While the lockdown restrictions continue to ease, the association says it is aware that things are still far from normal.A spokesman said distributing food parcels was one small way to help neighbours, relieve social isolation and improve the quality of le of the local community.Residents were grateful to receive non-perishable items and vacuum-packed fresh meat from Poole Butchers. The parcels also contained hand sanitiser bottles from Hinch Distillery.The spokesman added: ldquoSpa Wells Cultural Association would like to thank the Community Foundation for Northern Ireland, County Down Rural Community Network and Hinch Distillery for making this project possible..prettyPhoto

title: Tests on Newcastle Centre ground for redevelopment
story: GROUND condition tests at the site of the Newcastle Centre ahead of its major redevelopment are due to recommence shortly.Itrsquos understood the work will focus on land to the side and rear of the complex, including the outdoor Tropicana swimming pool which is not expected to reopen this summer. This particular facility could also be bulldozed as part of an ambitious redevelopment proposal.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is preparing to press head with investigative work at the prime Central Promenade location mdash including bore hole tests mdash to gather as much information as possible before it presses ahead with a multi-million pound investment.Council officials say that they recognise the need for modern leisure and community facilities at the site of the Newcastle Centre with several options on the table.They include a complete rebuild which include an extension to the existing centre, a complete refurbishment of the complex or partial rebuild and partial refurbishment.Retaining the Tropicana pool would restrict redevelopment proposals and the outdoor facility is most likely to be demolished, with enhanced car parking also set to be a key plank of any new proposal, in tandem with signicant disabled access improvements.A detailed feasibility study looked at a number of potential locations for a new leisure and community facility in the resort, with the Newcastle Centre site emerging as the firm favourite to house the new facility.Council officials say they are looking at a number of possibilities and that ldquoall options for the redevelopment of the town centre site are on the table.The existing Newcastle Centre forms part of the historic Annesley Buildings which enjoys protected status, but itrsquos believed that the cost of redeveloping the property and replacing the old extension at the rear would be signicant.It is also believed that an added problem facing the council is that the size of the existing centrersquos rooms are too small and unsuitable for modern needs. One possibility is that the facade of the current building would be retained, with a new-build at the rear.Council officials say that any plan to redevelop the Central Promenade site will not impact on any part of the promenade at the rear of the building.They insist that they are committed to the Newcastle project and recognise that it has a key role to play, meeting the needs of local people and visitors alike, particularly during inclement weather.It has also been confirmed that local people are to be asked for their views on redeveloping the site as part of a pre-planning application process, to come up with a favourable design.Senior council officials say that they recognise that as one of Northern Irelandrsquos premier tourist resorts, Newcastle does not have a modern indoor facility which has been its Achilles heel for some considerable time.Two sites were previously identied for a new leisure centre in the resort, with sports pitches at Donard Park the preferred option.However, councillors subsequently switched attention to the former St. Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School campus at Shanslieve Drive. Despite a number of attempts to secure the site and hopes that a deal could be agreed with local church officials, it was bought by supermarket giant Lidl.Politicians are keen for Newry, Mourne and Down Council to take the lead and ensure that a high class leisure community facility, which has been talked about in the resort for decades, is finally delivered.They insist that the provision of modern accommodation in the heart of Newcastle is long overdue and that the lsquoonce in a generationrsquo opportunity to deliver a modern, indoor facility must not be squandered.Some politicians say it is also critical to maximise every available square inch of space at the site to deliver a high quality centre..prettyPhoto
